== Tourism ==

La Paz is an important cultural center of Bolivia. The city hosts several cathedrals belonging to the colonial times, such as the San Francisco Cathedral and the Metropolitan Cathedral, this last one located on Murillo Square, which is also home of the political and administrative power of the country. Hundreds of different museums can be found across the city, the most notable ones on Jaén Street, which street design has been preserved from the Spanish days and is home of 10 different museums.
The home of the Bolivian government is located on Murillo Square and is known as "Palacio Quemado" (Burnt Palace) as it has been on fire several times. The palace has been restored many times since, but the name has remained untouched.


=== Principal attractions ===


==== Museums and cultural centers ====

The former home of Pedro Domingo Murillo, martyr of the independence revolution of 1809, has been preserved and is now a museum. The house displays a collection of furniture, textiles, and art from colonial times.
Museo Costumbrista: Displays ceramic dolls wearing traditional customs that show how was life in the early 19th century. Also on display are photos of old La Paz.
Museo Nacional de Arqueología (National Museum of Archeology): Depicts a collection of artifacts of the Tiawanaku culture.
Museo del Litoral (Museum of the Litoral Coastal Region): Displays objects from the 1879 war in which Bolivia lost its sea coast to Chile.
Museo del Oro (Gold Museum): Depicts pre-Conquest works made of gold, silver and copper.
Museo de Etnografía y Folklore (Ethnography and Folkolore Museum): Located in a house built during the late 18th century, it exhibits customs and art of two ethnic groups: Chipayas and Ayoreos.
Museo del Charango (Museum of Charango): Located in Calle Linares, the museum displays an important variety of charangos. Other native instruments are displayed as well.
Museo de Historia Natural (Natural History Museum): Exhibits on Bolivian paleontology, geology, zoology and botanical elements of interest.
Casa Museo Marina Nuñez del Prado (Marina Nuñez del Prado House Museum): Displays Quechua and Aymara-theme sculptures by Bolivian artist Marina Nuñez del Prado.
Museo Nacional de Arte (National Art Museum): Located in Calle Comercio, on a former palace built in 1775, displays works by Melchor Perez de Holguín and Marina Nuñez del Prado, among others.
Mercado de Brujas (Witches' Market): Merchandise sold here includes herbs, remedies as well as other ingredients used in Aymara traditions.
Feria de Alasitas: This fair is celebrated for two weeks each year, beginning January 24.  The central figure is a little god of abundance known as Ekeko, which means dwarf in Aymara.
Museo San Francisco Cultural Center


==== Churches and cathedrals ====

Metropolitan Cathedral, built in 1835 and located next to the Presidential Palace, on Murillo Square;
San Francisco Church, founded in 1548 and rebuilt 1784.

== Local festivals ==
January: Achocalla Festival: Occurs during the first week of January. The city of La Paz comes together to celebrate this religious festival with traditional dances, music, and a parade. In Bolivia's harvest calendar, Achocalla marks the time when potato fields begin to bloom. People dance the traditional folklore dance known as “tarqueada” during the festival.
January 24: Alasitas is a yearly fair where people buy miniature gifts and praise the god of prosperity, Ekeko. The fair begins every January 24 and lasts for a month.
February 2: Virgen de Copacabana, (Villa Copacabana)
May 1: San José Obrero (V. Nuevo Potosí)

May 14: San Isidro, Labrador (San Isidro)
May 17: Señor de la Sentencia (Villa Armonía)
May: Jesus, Señor del Gran Poder (movible, Gran Poder) La Fiesta del Gran Poder occurs according to the Saint's calendar. Therefore, it happens on different dates every year. But the festival typically occurs during late May to early June. This festival pays homage to El Señor del Gran Poder. During the festival, over 30,000 dancers take the streets of La Paz performing dances with themes that represent both Aymara folktales and Catholic traditions. The dancers wear colorful homemade costumes. The Parade lasts all day throughout the night.

== Transportation ==

Automobiles and public transportation are the main means to get into the city. In March 2012, more than 1.5 million vehicles were registered. Heavy traffic is common in the city center and traffic jams occur on peak hours.


=== Highways ===

The La Paz-El Alto Highway is a toll road that connects the city of La Paz with the neighboring city of El Alto. It is the city's main highway. It allows easy access to El Alto International Airport. The highway runs 11,7 km and crosses the city of El Alto:

 Autopista La Paz-El Alto/RN-3 (La Paz-El Alto Highway) - Connects La Paz with El Alto.
 Autovía La Paz Oruro/A-1 (La Paz-Oruro Highway)  - Connects La Paz with the cities of Oruro, Patacamaya and Caracollo. It then connects with Ruta Nacional 1/RN-1 (National Highway 1) heading south to the cities of Potosí, Camargo, Tarija.The Southern District, one of La Paz's most affluent and commercial neighborhoods, is relatively separated from the rest of the city, including the CBD. The Avenida Costanera and Avenida Kantutani (Costanera and Kantutani Avenues) connect the southern district with the rest of the metropolitan area.


=== Air ===

El Alto International Airport (IATA code: LPB) is La Paz's national and international airport and a principal hub for Línea Aérea Amaszonas and Transporte Aéreo Militar. It also serves as a focus city for Boliviana de Aviación, Bolivia's flag-carrier and largest airline. The airport is located in the city of El Alto and is (13 km) south-west of La Paz's city center. At an elevation of 4,061 metres (13,323 feet), it is the highest international airport and fifth highest commercial airport in the world. The runway has a length of 4,000 metres (2.5 mi). It is one of Bolivia's three main international gateways, along with Jorge Wilstermann International Airport and Viru Viru International Airport.
International carriers serving El Alto International Airport include Avianca, LATAM Airlines and Peruvian Airlines, which offer direct flights from La Paz to cities such as Bogotá, Lima, Santiago and Cusco. However, most international traffic, including flights to Europe, operated out of Viru Viru International Airport in Santa Cruz de la Sierra which is at a much lower altitude and is capable of handling larger aircraft.
Airport facilities include ATMs, cafés and restaurants, car rentals, duty-free shops, and free Wi-Fi internet. Additionally, the airport supplies travelers with oxygen for those who suffer from altitude sickness.


=== Bus ===

La Paz Bus Station, originally a bus and train station, was built by the French architect Gustave Eiffel. It is the main gateway for inter-city buses with several daily departures to all the main Bolivian cities, and routes to Chile and Peru. The city is connected by road with the city of Oruro from where there are routes to Sucre, Potosí and the south of the country. Another highway branches off before Oruro to reach Cochabamba and Santa Cruz. Roads to the west go to Copacabana and Tiwanaku, near Lake Titicaca, and continue to Cuzco, Peru via the border town of Desaguadero. There are also roads north to get to Yungas crossing the Andes Mountains.
Departures to smaller cities and towns within the department use informal stations located in Villa Fátima (departures to Los Yungas, Beni and Pando), Upper San Pedro (for Apolo) and near the General Cemetery (for Copacabana, Lake Titicaca, or via Tiwanaku to Desaguadero on the Peruvian border).


=== Cable car system ===

A system of urban transit aerial cable cars called Mi Teleférico ("My Cable Car") was opened in 2014. Eight lines are in operation, and three more lines are in the planning stage. The initial three lines were built by the Austrian company Doppelmayr. The first two lines (Red and Yellow) connected La Paz with El Alto. All stations have both a Spanish name and an Aymara name.


== Communications and media ==
The postal service is run by ECOBOL (National Company) which has its headquarters in La Paz. There are other companies offering courier and transport logistics courier nationally and internationally.
The private telecommunications company 'Entel' is located in the city and provides telephony, Internet, cell phone, data and voice services. The telephone cooperative Cotel is responsible for managing much of their phones and now offers Internet services and cable television among others.
Area Code: 2
Country Code: 591
The main daily newspapers in circulation are: Página Siete, La Razon, El Diario, La Prensa, Jornada and El Alteño. Other papers of local importance are: Extra and Gente. There are also several other publications and weekly magazines.
There are 18 television channels with offices in La Paz. Channel 7 is state property. The main ones are: Unitel, ATB Bolivia, Red Uno, Bolivision, Red PAT. Channel 13 is managed by the Universidad Mayor de San Andres. Two local companies offer cable television service as Multivision and Cotel TV.


== Water supply ==
The water supply of La Paz is threatened by the impact of climate change through the melting of glaciers. The city receives its drinking water from three water systems: El Alto, Achachicala and Pampahasi. La Paz shares the first and largest of these systems with its sister city El Alto. All three systems are fed by glaciers and rivers in the Cordillera mountain range. 20-28 % of its water is fed by glaciers, the remainder coming from rainfall and snowmelt. The glaciers recede as a result of climate change,  initially increasing water availability during the dry season, but ultimately threatening a substantial decrease in dry season run-off when they completely disappear. A small glacier, the Chacaltaya near El Alto, already disappeared in 2008. The El Alto system receives its water from the Tuni Dam and two water channels. These channels divert water that flows from the Zongo Glacier on the slopes of Huayna Potosi and from Condoriri North of El Alto. The 2.9 km long Zongo glacier retreats at a rate of about 18 meters per year. The Tuni and Condoriri glaciers have lost 39% of their area between 1983 and 2006. According to a study by the Stockholm Environment Institute (SEI), the El Alto system is the least resilient against the impact of climate change among the three systems. The study says that reducing water distribution losses is the most effective short-term strategy to deal with water scarcity. New water sources further to the North in the Cordillera include the Khara Kota and Taypicacha, but they are expensive to develop and their water supply is also affected by glacier melt.

What a lovely little area to explore and enjoy. Interesting art and museums, fun cafes and great photo opportunities. It had a really nice feel and we enjoyed our time here. Worth a visit when in La Paz.
Small & short colorful alley in the old city of La Paz. There are 2 museums there if you interested to visit them. However, It doesn’t worth the walk for it so don’t plan for it.
So much beautiful interesting art. Plus stunning old colonial architecture, hot coffee or mate & music.
Nice streets and would recommend going during the day (nighttime can get a bit dodgy leaving the area). But great spot to take photos
It's a nice walk down an old school and pedestrian road. There are several artisan shops, bars and restaurants.
This street is indicative of a past of the city. It is beautifull and makes onthink back to times that have gone by.

Such a contrast to most of central LaPaz, this beautiful street seems to invite you to wander down it's length and explore. Lot's of little nooks and great spots for photos. Cool cafes too for stopping a while and taking int he scene.
Several interesting small museums and art galleries are on this short street. Definitely worth the time to wander into them all. Well, most of them.

Beautiful street in the city centre, not so long but it has different museums, some crafts stores and restaurants or coffee places, so if go there you will be visiting the site about two hours and a half (museums included) Architecture is well conservated. Great place to

If you have been to other cities in South America with a colonial city centre then you could possibly skip this one. I did not because you never what you are going to find and this one was remarkably pleasant.

Went here as part of an organised full day tour with Transturin. It is one of the only what I would call traditional historic streets left in La Paz, the buildings are beautiful and colourful the street is cobbled and on a small incline. If in La Paz visit here. There are a
One of the nicest (if not the nicest) streets in La Paz. Small street with some shops, museum and some history.

A neat little backsteet thathas no traffic and do not underestimate that as a huge attraction in this city. The Museum of musical instruments is first class, there are a number of restaurants and small shops but its not spectacular in a tourist sense
Beautiful pedestrian street full of museums, shops, and one hipster cafe/wine bar. Too bad it was just so short...

just dont miss it. though we were late for museum visit , a stroll through Jaen Street ( tough to pronounce - there is no "J". Calm and beutiful , architecture ..colourful. night must be more romantic. Had coffee from the coffee house just next to museum. very sweet -place
It is just a short and average street. It has got a couple of colonial buildings, but don't bother to come here if it's not on your way...
If you're in La Paz, it is certainly worth visiting Jaen Street, a well preserved and good looking relic of La Paz's colonial past. It is quite narrow and very quaint.
enough museums to keep mesuem hollicks occupied for the day, from instruments to art, to precious metals. Good cafes too.
This street is short and narrow with cute facades on colourful buildings. Worth a look and to take a few pictures but I wouldn't go out of the way to find it.

We walked up to Jaen St having been told that it was a good place to go to. Jaen St is quaint with original buildings. The museums however were not well laid out and the house was restricted to two rooms. I would not recommend it as a site to see in La Paz except to wander down
I stayed in a hostel on this street so it was a short hop to 4 small museums that this area is known for. Note the lovely cobblestone/rock detail on this little winding lane.
Worth exploring the area, many museums and galleries. Nice artisan types of shop but beware they are closed on Sat afternoon and Sunday. There some interesting colonial architecture.

This street has so much history. You can go to four government run museums for a small fee: The House of Murillo (the man who started the revolution against the Spaniards), the Museum of Precious Metals, the Litoral Museum (military/history of the access to the sea), and the

Calle Jaen is not very long, but it was very pretty and there were plenty of beautiful colors up and down the street. It's a great spot to take pictures, and there are also a few museums, tour agencies, art galleries, and cafes along the way to stop at. We made the walk up the
Had walked through this street and was still looking for it. Narrow street about 150m long. You are at the end of it while still looking for it. Nothing really there.

The cobblestone street had several colourful houses, which made it nicer than the usual streets in La Paz. However, the entire street was very short (perhaps 100m?) and there were just several artisan shops and one cafe open in the late afternoon. Not quite worth going out of

Of You wanna See a really old beautiful street in La Paz go there. We Just found this recommendation and got some really nice Pictures. You also will find 4 Museums and a few hand crafts Shops in that street.

It's a cobbled street with small artisan shops n museums. The museums do shut at about 5pm. A few interesting art shops but unfortunately, i didnt see something which is really Bolivian that I can buy as a souvenir to bring back to the UK. I guess it's worth a visit/walk to this
Nice cobbled street to walk through and back. I missed the hustle and the vendors like in Linares and Sagarnatha area.

This rather narrow, short, cobbled street is a must see in La Paz. It gets a bit crowded with tourists, but the colours, the architectural detail and the four museums along the route are all worth seeing. Plus there are artsy shops and places to eat. The museums are closed

An awesome colonial street, still keeps its original house facades, and stone road. Now has museums, bars, touristics shops; Even many people says that this place is haunted, cause has a green cross on one of his walls... And believe me, the best absent on the city...

In my opinion this is the best Colonial street in La Paz. It is peatonal and it has a lot of very pretty colourful houses with the added value that national hero Murillo lived there. Good stroll, good cafes, nice place
Beautiful street with nice museums. The architecture is a lot nicer than in the rest of La Paz and it's close to the center.
My most favourite place whole in La Paz! There is a museum telling you a history of La Paz and also a little cozy cafe by the museum (my favourite!) You shouldn't miss out this place I swear!

A small street locates one block away from the municipal theater where you can experience colonial La Paz. Museums and galleries are open in the daytime, while cafes and pubs come alive at night. Many places also feature live music/entertainment on the weekends and will usually

Jaén Street offers a look at old La Paz that does not exist any more. A narrow street with well preserved old houses that have become museums and coffee shops. A pleasant stroll either with a group or on your own

This is one of the few streets in La Paz that have maintained their colonial touch. The street is narrow, with balconies from different houses facing one another. They are almost close enough for neighbours to shake hands or share apples (by tossing them over, of course). The

The street is quite short but you can wander into the art galleries and there are shops and restaurants nearby. It's well preserved and photogenic. You'll see some tour groups being led down here but it is also used by the locals.

I had a business trip in la paz so I tried to know some places..this street is like magic you can find a lot of museums.. stores to bye souvenirs you can see a lot of tourists.. And near also some bars that are beautiful not just typical bars..so if you want something different
Great place! There are six museums in one place and great pics can be taken here. You can hear about some good stories here.

Honestly, we did not like La Paz, but this little street is nice. Cobblestoned and colonial style, it is peaceful and beautiful. Probably overrated in the brochures, but nice to spend a relaxing walk through.
It is included in every travel book or on many city maps. But this street is under average and has not much to offer, a bit boring.

Different look and feel from the test of La Paz. The tour company for the walking tour is here. They say this place is haunted. There's a green cross on one end of the street to ward off spirits. Apparently this street is known to ghost hunters.
Nice cobble stone street lined with colourful colonial buildings housing nice shops. Very much worth walking through.
It's a nice, narrow, cobble stone little street where time seems to have stopped sometime ago. Nothing spectacular, just a taste of the past and worthy of a little stroll ...
Quiet small street so worth walking too. It's nice to get out of the major crowds of LaPaz and this was a pleasant place to do that.
This was a nice way to spend a sunny afternoon. Jaen street has lots to do and see with a few museums and cafes along this cobble stone way.
This a historical street in La Paz. It is a neat walk on coble stone street. Has access to lots of museums, such as the Museum of Musical Instruments. Take a camera and have fun.
Very interesting this neighbourhood. Many buildings from colonial times recpvered and in very good state of conservation. There are many handicraft shops with amazing items.
This is a nice little street, there is a 3 or 4 museum. Little shop. It's very quiet. There is a park not to far to relax
There are many streets in La Paz and this is one of them. It is nice and if you are going down it, enjoy, but don't cross town just to come here.
We stayed on a hostel on this street and I would highly recommend it. There were lots of really cute eateries but I didn't visit the museums.

Not as colourful or cool as I was expecting. There are quite a few museums but they didn't excite us too much. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to go there, but it's not like you'd be too disappointed going there
Many of the museums are on this street. The lane itself is quaint, peaceful, and a great stroll from shop to shop (arts and crafts, arts galleries, craftman's Shops etc.)
Cute little street with a hostel and some tour agencies and museums. Not necessarily a tourist attraction in itself, but nice if you want to see the museum of musical instruents
Its just a street to walk up, that has been kept in its original condition but will give you an idea of the architecture of centuries gone by.

Visiting the Jaen Street museums was a delight. The system is well organized: one ticket allows a visit to several of the museums. Some, but not all of the museums had information in other than Spanish.

as the other reviewers say, it is a cute but very short street. It only has a handful of shops and a couple of nice coffee shops but other than that it is just a street. my advice is pop along if you are nearby but don't go out of your way to find it
Nice little street with small stones embedded into the roads and the buildings still in great condition. Not a must do if your time is limited

This is only colonial street in good shape remaining in La Paz. So it is a very special and charming block. Over the years, what used to be just regular houses, is being transformed into touristy shops. Still it has that charm. Full of legends and you can visit at least 5
this is a very charming street to visit and it contains three important museums to be visited: the Musical Instruments' Museum, the Litoral Museum, the Murillo House Museum, and the Metals' Museu.
It seems to be the most beautiful street of La Paz. It was nice to find very good coffee in artsy ETNO cafe, also interesting art gallery.
Jean Street was close to my hotel (El President - Avoid). It's a nice walk up there. The street itself is quaint but I really would not go out of my way to see it.

The street itself is quite charming but the main attractions are the museums. There are four museums near the top of the street which must be bought as a package: Museo de Metales Preciosos, Museo del Litoral, Casa de Murilla, and Museo Costumbrista Juan de Vargas. At the bottom

Soner or later most La Paz visitors walk along Jaen Street. And so should you. The architecture is very interesting--lots of balconies. The shops are plentiful as are the art galleries. People watching is always a good past time, and Jen Street is a good place for it.

This street has lots of interesting architecture and artist shops to visit as you walk along this street. I bought a little carved painted box that was made by a local artist and it is one of my favorite souvenirs!

before the spanish colonists build the city on 1548, there was the lama market. Now you find nice shops where young bolivian artist sell there handicrafts. It change from the shops of the calle Sagarnaga
This is one of the old historical Street here.A must for tourists anyhow your guide will take you here on the city tour.

Jaen street is a nice, just nice street. Walking in the street is quite lovely, nothing spectacular about it but different from the other streets in La Paz. You can take nice pictures in some part of the street.

To be honest this street is a bit overrated I think. We took a photo but outside of that its just a street with a bit of colour. If you really appreciate things like this I'd suggest valparaiso in chile. As for the musuems we specifically wanted to visit them but we had to
Quaint colonial street that houses several museums , although we were there at the posted opening hours, two of which were closed, so rather disappointing.
Very historic street in La Paz that is hard to appreciate without the knowledge of a good guide. Many tours walk through this street which is an important location to the history of the city.

with such a rich colonial and republican past, shouldn't this not only be a street but a whole district? is is so small, the musea so unattractive and it is at the top of every tour guide i see, i very much prefer the natural outdoors things in la paz

If we had only few hours in La Paz, this is the street I would want to see again. Narrow lovely street with several museums, very well preserved buildings, with typical southamerican balconies, clean, unassuming... Next time would try to stay in the only accommodation on this
A stunning multi-coloured surprise in the middle of an unpromising area. Some nice little artesan shops as well.
A very lovely street in La Paz, the most colonial example in La Paz and is a very tranquil and beautiful street.

This is a very unique little street, very neat and pretty but I'll be honest I much prefer the more interesting streets that criss cross the area of the witches market. La Paz for me was one of the most interesting cities in S. America.

The street itself is quite charming - but it's short and can be done in a few minutes if you're not planning on visiting any of the museums. We had hoped for a decent bar to have a drink, but there was nothing but one dark looking pizza place with plastic chairs there (at least

Arriving mid morning, this historic street was deserted, but bcame busier as midday neared. The museums were interestingbut with no English translations for displays we were left to figure out for ourselves what many artefacts were. The tiny entrance fee meant this really wasn't

I had high hopes for Jaen Street after reading so much about it being one of the few preserved colonial streets. It is quite cute with cobbled streets and older preserved buildings. It is also home to several small museums at are very popular and interesting. But the
It's a really cute place to visit while in La Paz. It gives you an idea how the city looked like some 150 years ago. Just stroll down and enjoy. It won't take you long though. Worth visiting.
Its a beautiful street is very old and is like going a hundred years back in the past. There is a great bar ETNO.

- You will chance upon this street when wandering around the streets of La Paz. - Very pretty alley street with many colors. - Yes, this is a good spot for photos. And trust me, you will not be disappointed because your photos will turn out really clear from the high altitude.

Quaint street but nothing special, full of tedious, dull museums, the street is just like anyother, no idea why it got as many postive reviews.
five museums including the music instrument museum. several little shops selluing artisanat and / or organic quinoa. Sevaral little bars and hostels. Very quiet since it is a pedestrian zone
Cafes, museums, old architecture, and plenty of charm. This is a delightful place to stroll with no cars. Be sure to look in on the museum of the Pacific.
Jaen has some really hip shops and cafes. Definitely a cool place to hang out and relax. Nice art galleries.
This beautiful area and street shows La Paz as it was 100 years ago. It is very authentic with several meusems and old houses. Very nice to visit for a couple of hours

Don Pedro Domingo Murillo who headed the revolution of 1809, his house is now a museum...and there are 3 or 4 close by museums...it.s worth to walk ..lil .hard to find but is very close to San Francisco plaza

This street is probably one of the best looking streets in La Paz, we went at midday and were the only ones there. There are museums to visit, and I imagine the street comes alive to those with a guide and more information. Worth a look if you are staying nearby. There are some
Our group did enjoy this this shot and narrow street that provided historical 19th century feel. Street takes you to excellent ethnic museum and nearby plaza.

This is a must visit in La Paz. The Jaen Street is full of museums worth visiting and is a great activity for a nice day in La Paz. I wouldn't go with small children since there aren't many things for them to do (only the Musical Instruments Museum would be suitable for kids)

The Calle Jaen is a small cobbled street a short walk (15 minutes approx) away from Plaza Murrillo. Worth it....very well restored buildings which have tasteful little shops at the bottom opening up onto the windy cobble stoned lane. At the top of the lane there are a number of

Not sure I would make a huge effort to visit. Perhaps we timed it wrong as it was very quiet (Monday lunchtime) with a lot of the shops/museums being closed. Yes, it is quiet and cobbled and quaint but I was expecting a lot more.
It's a very special little street, very different from other areas of the city... I recommend that you go during the afternoon and ask around for the stories of the street.
Nice example of what La Paz use to look like in terms of architecture and cobble streets. The street has some great little art galleries - at reasonable prices. Great spot for a cup of tea or coffee!
the street is what we imagine La Paz was 70 years ago..the museums are great and the cute little stores and cafes around will make a great half a day visit

Worth the trip if for no other reason than being the oldest street. However, it's also very charming, with the intricate balconies being my favorite. Several museums are clustered in the area, and the gallery/shop of Mamani Mamani is close by. I would recommend stopping by
A surprising beautiful restored street that is worth a visit. A lot of museums and small shops, and the best, no traffic!

Short and iconic colonial street in old La Paz historic district. Alost each house over the street is a Museum, some of them as good as the Musical Instruments Museum that charango master musician Ernesto Cavour has build over the years, single-handed and just because of his
A bit of a walk for such a short street. Not sure I would recommend going although the shops seemed nice and the museums (although shut when we arrived) sound quirky.

Granted, I was usually coming around during the evenings, but surprised to find everything closed, except once one bar was open and the guys were friendly. Should be a hip little street as written up in guidebooks but personally I found it to be dead and disappointing.
Calle Jaen is a short cobblestone street about four blocks from Plaza Murillo. The colonial era houses have been fully restored and house museums, shops and restaurants. Try Etno for lunch or dinner.
Beautiful street, that deserves a visit. Very interesting the Mamani Mamani Art Gallery. Amazing work of the artist that involves the Andean Cosmovision.

For some reason this street is on every "must-do" list for La Paz, but for me, (not a HUGE museum guy), it was just your average narrow street in La Paz. I did visit a couple of the museums, such as the museum of Bolivian musical instruments, and grabbed a coffee at Etno
representing historic la paz... museums, restaurants and café / wine bars -- a great distraction for an afternoon!!
Picturesque and touristy like Montmartre in Paris. Not quite our cup of tea. The museums in the street are cute but nothing to call home about.

Perhaps there are hidden historic dimensions to this area that I was not aware of, but although pleasant to stroll the cobbled streets, unless you like wandering into small not too gripping "museums" there is not too much to hold your attention. But, that said , it makes a calm

We saw this street, briefly when we went to visit the Musical Instrument Museum (also highly interesting!)... amazing what a coat of paint and a 'make-over' can do to a place/street/village/hotel/Restaurant/home anywhere!!!!!!!!!!!

I visited on a Sunday so not much was open but it's a gorgeous, clean street that still maintains the classic buidlings from the 19th century. The museums there are nice but not great though they don't cost much. It's a must see in La Paz for cultural purposes.

it was nice to walk up and down but we we went early in the morning and late in the afternoon (to check out a coffee shop we'd seen) but everything was shut both times. Get a tour with Banjo Tours and they'll explain a little about it. Mornings are better to visit because

As reported by other reviewers, all musea were closed end December/early January. Without the musea the street has nothing special: many colonial towns have nicer streets. If you also visit Cuzco don't waste time here.

Increable, all musea are closed for at least one month! This will not help the tourism in thia country. Although the street by it self is very nice and well restored, closing these musea is a complete failure..
Calle Jaen - a street in La Paz. The only impressiv - the cleanness. You can see the old stone mosaics on the street with out the waste in the rest of the city.

For La Paz, the short Spanish-era street is unique, with its lacey iron balconies. However, let's face it, you would not give it a second look in Europe or elsewhere in Latin America. Still it's very nice if you are in the neighbourhood. It would have been GREAT if the museums

A good visit if you have some time left. There are 4 small museums, that you can visit with 1 cheap ticket (10 boliviano's). One of the museums is closed for the moment. Especially the house of Murillo is worthwhile. Photo's are forbidden.

Delightful short pedestrian street with colonial architecture, 5 small museums, and art galleries. However, two of the museums ( the Metals or Oro (gold) museum and the musical instruments museum ) were closed for several months, but its difficult to find this out beforehand.

Quaint little street above the city center. There are five museums located along the street, along with a few shops and cafes. The problem with it is that the four city-run museums keep odd and very short hours - generally opening for just a couple of hours in the morning and

Great to see that the Bolivian government can beautify at least some small part of their city. It may only take 5 minutes to amble down (or up) this street, but it is great to see this restored old colonial street. Their are several cafes and craft shops along its length to add

I went to this street, and it is a lovely street with many interesting museums which are open in the morning, then close, and then open again at 3:00 pm. Unfortunately, we hit the street around 1:00 pm. We walked down the street, and shopped. I especially enjoyed the gallery at

Gold, metal, music, art and others are represented in these museums. One of the most interesting is the building that was once the home of don Pedro Domingo Murillo, a leader in the La Paz Revolution of July 16, 1809, with its displays of period furniture and paintings.

This is a narrow, historic, cobbled street where there is a group of small museums run by the La Paz Municipality. It is very attractive and photogenic with several shops selling artisania. You can buy the entry ticket for the museums in the one on the main road and then visit

This street has colorful colonial buildings with balconies. There are also several museums here which we were unable to visit. The street itself is an attractive enough reminder of a bygone era, just don't expect to be bowled over.
It's so bad that the colonial area in La Paz is pretty much limited to Calle Jaen. The buildings are beautiful, and the area really quite, with nice stores and cafes.

This street is beautiful! We were there on a holiday, so almost nothing was open on the street, but that was almost better. We had the street to ourselves! It looks so picturesque, so beautiful. It's worth going to Jaen Street just to walk down it and see the architecture. What

The well-preserved, quaint, stoned road is a welcome surprise if coming from the big, crowded, noisy boulevards and street markets of the rest of La Paz. At the lower end of the road is an elders' home with sweet folks sitting in the sun and feeding pigeons. The colors of the

Okay so the 4 museums were closed (easter sunday) but we popped in the the muscial instrument museum which was fun to have a go on some of the instruments. We took a few pictures and found a nice art gallery at the end. So some might say not a lot to do but it was a little

Only 3 of the 4 small museums were open when we visited (the gold and silver museum was closed), but it was still fun. The street is lovely with all the charm of the 18th centery. The buildings that the museums are set in were beautiful. The displays looked great, but we had no

Oldest street in town that still looks like the 18th century. Lots of fun pubs like Etno and Boca y Sapo to enjoy the evening. Plus all the museums that concentrate around that area. Really worth a while visiting.
Colorful, from past colonial times. Nice short walk. Would not recommend walking around at night though.

This street is exactly what I was expecting in La Paz. It is small and quaint with some nice souvenir shops. I didn't visit the museums as I had gone quite late in the afternoon. Ended up buying a nice small bag made by an indigenous tribe.
Sure it is not going to take up a whole day, but this is a lovely street to have a coffee, visit a couple of the cute museums and buy some gifts. It was by far my favourite street in La Paz!

The historical concept is nice and there is novelty in some of the products, but this gathering of stores feels just like another photo shoot opportunity and the chance to buy some bizarre products. Each staff seems to carry the same stuff.

4 museums for a ridiculously low price. Each museum is very small, and the exhibitions aren't that interesting. To make things worse, we paid for all 4 museums, even though one of them was closed for renovations. On top of that, in only one museum the explanations were provided
Excellent place to pick up gifts and souvenirs. The Mamani Mamani studio is located at the end of the street. Well worth the trip.
Very pretty street! The four museums there are quite interesting (and cheap to get into) but there really are minuscule. 90 minutes for all four is plenty!
A cool alley way filled with cute stores and a few great museums. Check out the museum of instruments!! Very interesting!! Good way to fill an hour or so.
Unless you are heading to one of the museums on the street there's no point going. Cafes are small darks dn overpriced.
a great place to gomfor a drink or a delicious meal. we ate the best pizza in bolivia. dont miss that while in la paz.
Make sure you save an hour or so to hit this street! Cool architecture, nice shops! Worth an hour or so!

Take a stroll away from the hustle and bustle of the La Paz streets and enjoy the beautiful feel of the cobbled back roads where the mothers hurry along with their children and the locals walking about or sitting outside their homes. We stopped to buy ice cream from a tiny shop
Nice and beautiful bulidingd, colonial style painted in colors...

Wonderfully picturesque cobbled street in La Paz with some tempting-looking restaurants. Visited early afternoon and we were the only tourists there. Would like to have visited the museums but we still had a lot of the city to see.

Save your shopping dollars for this street! Unique gifts, nice people and a quiet reprieve from the bustle and diesel of La Paz!

This is an amazingly photogenic street and has some museums on it. Unfortunately we went on a Sunday and everything on it was closed, but we got some amazing photos and a lovely view of La Paz as it was two hundred years ago. Well worth the uphill walk!
Great uphill narrow, colonial street wih beautiful houses, museums and Etno Café & Pub, certainly the best place to chill out with local made 70% absynth. Can't miss this!

Besides it's a street where most museums could be found, it's a historical beautiful colonial place, full of tour agencies and cafes for tourists. Don't miss it!
Small & short colorful alley in the old city of La Paz. It doesn’t worth the walk for it so don’t plan for it.

Too much culture in a small place.

Much smaller area that I expected but it was nice to walk through it.
Nice and historical street with a lot of small museums.
Nice little street, worth a stroll.

:) Nice colored houses, but don't expect too much
Historic place, colorful alley

Nice colorful street with some art galleries.

sights.name: The Arch of Cabo San Lucas

text.wiki:
The arch of Cabo San Lucas, is a distinctive rock formation at the southern tip of Cabo San Lucas, which is itself the extreme southern end of Mexico's Baja California Peninsula.  The arch is locally known as "El Arco," which means "the arch" in Spanish, or "Land's End."It is here that the Pacific Ocean becomes the Gulf of California.
This area is widely used in hotel advertising in the Los Cabos Corridor. This spot is a popular gathering area for sea lions and is frequented by tourists. It is three stories tall and was formed from natural erosion. The Arch of Cabo San Lucas is adjacent to Lovers Beach on the Sea of Cortez side and Divorce Beach on the rougher Pacific Ocean side. The Arch is accessible by land if you approach it by placing yourself at the beach of the last hotel on the Pacific ( Finisterra )
You will have to climb some big rocks, once you do that, you will be at the very tip of the peninsula and a few steps from El arco.Basement rock in Los Cabos formed through intrusive igneous processes c. 115 million years ago, during the Cretaceous period.
 


== References ==
text.quote: A well-known area landmark, this rock formation jutting out from the ocean is shaped like an arch.

it became one of our favorite places we have ver visited, we loved the sense of scale of el arco, we recommend you this place it is the number 1 atraction,we also recommend Jw Italian Restaurant for a good dinner, also for your transportation at your arrival from cabo airport
This is THE landmark in all of cabo so there were lots of boats crushing around for the right photo op
Booked our tour using a clear boat from our hotel Tesoro Los Cabos. It was $50 US dollars for two persons. Great experience!

The place which makes me so happy and attracts people which makes me so happy to be there happy to be there

The Arch and Lovers Beach is always one of my must do's when I visit Cabo. This is a nostalgic move on my part.

Don't miss a boat trip out to this beautiful landmark. every 4 years the tide goes out far enough that you can walk under it. I'd love to come back to do that.
This is a very unique site that you need to see in your lifetime! Thousands of years in the making!!

There are less expensive rides over by the Office resturant. We ate lunch and was then offered a 35 min boat ride out to the arch and divorce beach for 10 bucks a head which was a deal based on the prices quoted to us at the marina.
Get a glass bottom boat! But make sure it is actually glass bottom and not just a hole to look through! Or, book a trip that will let you get off and walk around by the arch.
We went on a five hour fishing trip. On the way back into the marina near the arch, the mate sets a few bait fish on the deck. Sea lions jump in the back of the boat for a snack!

This was a return trip for us and it didn't disappoint, the waters are beautiful and calm on the day we went, the Arch was amazing, it is a must see when in Cabo. There are plenty of sea lions to see and the whales were out swimming with their babies.

This rock formation is unique to Cabo and is worth visiting to see the seals that live there. We took it in as part of a fishing trip and would have liked to stop and visit the sandy beach next to it.
Wow the people , the place, the food, the hotel! everything was perfect! enjoyed to fullest. went to attend big fat wedding,
Sailed around Los Arcos from the harbor to the Pacific side. Saw pelican rock, sea lions, marlin, and humpback whales! Would highly recommend this sailing.

I had read about the reviews of this attraction, but none of them can give it the justice. Until you are there seeing the Arco de Cabo, you will not belive your eyes and while on the boats, make sure you take the opportunity for photo ops.
this place is so iconic this is the symbol of cabo very beautiful smooth water on my trip a must do while in cabo

A water taxi can drop you off if you want to go exploring on what is also called Lover's Beach, but the site of the Arch that marks Lands End is also a wonderful trip if you don't exit the water taxi. "Lovers Beach" is also where they filmed "Planet of the Apes" so you'll feel
Its like the Grand Canyon of Arizona, or the Statue of Liberty for New York. Must see if you're visiting Cabo San Lucas.

We took an 2 1/2 boat tour from the marina and thru EI Arco and out to the Pacific side to see the breach and it ways absolutely awe inspiring! The whales are some of the most majestic animals on this planet! I went with my son and grandchildren and we really enjoyed the cruise!

The famous arch really is cool to see. It is only accessible by boat and their are so many possibilities. I was surprised about how close it really is to downtown. We went on a whale watching 2 hour tour which was quite fun. However, note that the seas are a lot rougher out
Beautiful we saw seals and scenery for days! The dinner cruise was good 2.5 hours long and the music was great.
This is a must see attraction when visiting in the Baja Peninsula. The sight is breath-taking. I have been to Cabo 7 times and everytime I visit, this is a must see adventure.
The iconic arches! A must see when you come to Cabo! You can even do a whale watching trip as part of this during the right times of year!
I highly recommend, this was my first time to visit Cabo for my 50th bday!!! Absolutely stunning, and we will be back asap!

This was an amazing experience, if you want something to do on a cloudy day and the sun wasn’t beating down on you, this is a amazing experience, they fed you and the drinks were poured, the grandchildren loved it... they got to see whales, and of course the arch. Would actually
Not much more to see close up than what you see from a distance. Don't take a special trip to see it.
We took a fishing trip and whale watching cruise and saw this view. The whales were active and the locals are friendly.

We had a great time on the Cabo Escape Sunset Dinner .... The boat crew fixed a great meal and the music was perfect for practicing the Salsa Dance I learned at La Sirena Del Mar. The boat stopped at great spots for beautiful sunset pics!

We found out that most excursions will take you past this area. That means you will have plenty of photo opportunities. If you go on a tour, the guide will tell you all of the rock formations that look like animals and figures. Make sure you allow time to explore Lovers Beach.

That’s right, this old saying is very appropriate when visiting Cabo as this famous rock formation where Sea of Cortez meets Pacific Ocean is most visited and photographed artifact in all of Cabo. Not only Arc is the subject of the pictures, if you look closely you can also

This is the icon of Cabo San Lucas.. be sure to find a boat rental and get out on the water..many rock formations to view and take pictures. This area of Cabo is busy with tourists, everyone wants to see this icon.
A great place to see an Iconic landmark for mexico , $25 per person should get you a comfortable 1.5 hour boating experience
If you don't like lovers beach you can walk over to divorce beach. Beautiful. You can snorkel there. Travel from the Marina in a glass bottom boat. Great place to get great pictures.
Very beautiful place, you cannot miss that in Cabo San Lucas! You've to see that. I was in the sea when I took pictures and the result is crazy.
We were on the whale watching tour with Cabo Adventures and part of the trip was seeing El Arco! Beautiful sight. We had a great day with Mario as our guide.

Every one have to visit this place. I’m in love with this place. Is a paradise. Have to take cruise to the beach of love. And prom ine side of Sea of Cortes to the Pacific Ocean. Make sure if they give you one price just make ask for better price and they will give discount.

El Arco is also known as Lands End. This distinctive rock formation is located at the extreme southern end Mexico's Baja California Peninsula where the Sea of Cortez joins the Pacific Ocean You will see many sea lions here and can be visited by a water taxi from the pier.

Ok this area is breath taking. It looks even better than the pictures you see in the magazine. Now because of that its crowed and the smaller boats tend to get up alot closer than the larger ones so dont expect to get the most amazing pictures cause there is going to be

It probably doesn't matter which boat tour you book as most will do the same but I can definitely recommend a short trip out to El Arco. You'll most likely stop on a few things on the way out there and it's nice to see El Arco close up. Most likely, you can also spend some time
Don't say yes right away. Private boats are negotiable. Leaving the cruise tender, turn right & there are many opportunities

See the Arch is a ‘must see’ if you are in the marina area Los Cobos. You can take. Water Taxi, or almost any boat tour passes by it. When the water is a little rough, you get the classic splashing of the waves. Along the way you see the small beaches that you can only reach
MUST see, if you visit Cabos !! Take a sunset cruise to take in this breathtaking scenery. Highlight of out trip.
My best experience of all at Los Cabos, this place is amazing, I really recommend this tour to all travelers

This natural arch creates a picturesque setting for photography and adventure. If you are lucky enough to sail around Land's End on your visit here, you can take some incredible photos. We were here on our sixth cruise and never get tired of seeing this iconic symbol of Cabo.
A must do boat trip to the arch Was 10usd per person left rate in front on the sante fe lovers beach and divorce beach and the scenery are all very beautiful

We took a water taxi out to the arch and enjoyed the area more than we initially thought. Numerous photo opportunities. There is a large walking area on both sides and beach to lounge or swim. Unique and well worth experiencing.
We did a sailing adventure with Cabo Adventures. Only go through them. Wonderful crew and unique experience

We cruised by the Arc on a caborey sunset dinner boat and it was just amazing! I recommend everyone who visits Cabo to try to do a tour around the Arc. The rock formation is so cool to see and at sunset it makes it feel even more amazing. Highly recommended! The photos I took
If you didn't go out into the sea where the Pacific meets the Sea of Cortez, to see this from up close... you can't say you visited Cabo, lol

Water was warm enough to snorkel, but could be a bit warmer. Went on Carnival Miracle cruise. The trip there and back was a bit chilly, couldn’t really be on the deck of the ship swimming in the pool, hot tubs were packed so couldn’t do that either. If you like cruises, inside

The Arch, Lovers Beach, Divorce Beach and The Eye to the Pacific are must-sees. Awe-inspiring beauty at it's finest. Don't waste your money on an overpriced boat with bells, whistles, free booze (read: watered down drinks) or food. Take a water taxi for about $20 and enjoy the
Centrepiece of Cabo! We took a $10 water taxi return from the locals in front of the Riu Hotel on the beach.
beautiful beach safe for swimming. Water taxi takes you from marina across to el arco, easily accessed.

We made an arrangement with Pepe from Rice and Beans Tour Operators to take us to El Arco for a few hours. It is SO beautiful with Lovers Beach and Divorce Beach on opposite sides. This is a must do! Be sure to heed the warning and do not go into the Pacific Ocean.... clearly
We took a tour on a clear boat and it was the most amazing experience. Our 5 year old loved it and baby actually fell asleep. I would definitely recommend this.

We spent a couple of hours here enjoying the cliffs and beach taking pictures and my uncle flew his drone here and got some great shots of the gorgeous water and rock formations.... they sell beverages here and small snacks....
We took a whale watching boat tour and it stopped near the rocks first. Very pretty to see up close.

Pretty to look at and drive by - nature is awesome. 2 pics from sunrise and one from mid afternoon. In the morning no one was there is was peaceful. In the afternoon so many glass bottom boats were in the area and the marina really was bumpin..lovers beach is around the corner
This place, is just magical! The sand and sea is lovely and clear. Loads of fish, sea lions and pelicans.
going to cabo and not visiting the arch, oh god, there is something wrong with you. must take this activity

We were fortunate to travel to the Arc with David on a private boat that we got from the Sur Beach Restaurant water sports area on Medano beach. He made the experience truly special with his music, informative talk, professional photo taking, friendliness and boating
This iconic area was viewed by boat. Lots of photo ops and had great weather which helped tremendously.
We attended this tour set up by the Hard Rock. It was a fun time although short. Crew was fun and we enjoyed it.
My family and i love to visit the arch, it is wonderful and,my grandparents used to tell me stories about the arch since i was a Child and it is a tradition to visit the arch if you visit los Cabos!

My husband and I checked this out via a water taxi we hired from the marina for 400 pesos (we had a private water taxi for just the two of us). The taxi took us out to the arch, allowing us to see Lover's Beach, Divorce Beach, the Arc, and some of the other rocks and sea lion

Fun! Bring a beach umbrella & snacks and drinks Waves are rough for small kids Water clear and warm. Went the first week of December- the glass bottom boat dropped us off and picked us up 1.5 hours later
This is a must see tourist attraction that Cabo SanLucas is known for. There are a variety of tours to get you there. Great natural Arch to see on a sunset tour.
This was one of our excursions of Cabo . We took a scenic tour about 45 min in length that shows area of Cabo

Los Arcos, a series of rock formations that jut out from the coast of Baja California Sur, is featured on all the ads for Cabo San Lucas. As well it should be. Los Arcos marks the junction of the Pacific Ocean with the Gulf of California ( or the Sea of Cortez, as it's known
this is a tour that is a MUST!!!! the sunset tour is incredible, the best season is november it is not hot, it is warm not so cold, you will see sealions and the arc is amazing.
Water taxi combined with Lovers beach afternoon is a great combo trip. Beautiful sand, fish, sealions and more.
Great boat ride very reasonably priced. Beautiful beaches . We will visit again. Great family value. Never had spent Christmas on the beach
Beautiful and a very heavily visited tourist location. A great picture spot and very romantic. I'd suggest to go early and take a lunch.

Took a water taxi at the Marina cost USD15. It was late in the afternoon so only 2 of us riding the whole boat. Good to take photos without other people. The ocean was a bit rough but no worries as you must wear a life vest. The Arch was stunning which is a must if you visit
I have taken a tour each time in Cabo and they have included a trip to the El Arco. This such a beautiful rock formation and it was awesome seeing the sea lions. Definitely a must see!
Must see site ! Near by you will see whales & dolphins breaching . Take a jacket with you as even if you need not need one , you will be happy you took one for the ride
Lands end Cabo san Lucas. Took a trip on a sailing ship. When we saw the sunset we took a stop. Seriously, take a trip on a sailing ship to see this.

I’ve been coming to Cabo since the late 80’s. Los Archos made an impression on me back then & continues to today. The most beautiful time is at sunrise when the warm orange/red sun highlights the rocks. I often go out fishing and passing by the arch in a boat at sunrise. It’s
Glass bottom boat tour for $10 USD per person. Bought on beach at Medano beach. Barter. We decided not to stop at Lover's beach but was given that option.

Stunning! The arch were very beautiful! The boat ride was about 30 min. We hired a tour guide right by the shore for a very decent price. Look around first for different guides because the prices vary.
Paradise on earth! 2.5 hours of out of the world experience.. truly amazing! We were luck to see a few whales too Hope on your flight & make your next stop here !
There’s a lot of sellers who will look for your business. An average trip to see the arco is about 230-250 pesos. That includes the tour to the arco and all the nearby beaches.
Once again, amazing. This was our 2nd trip out to see it and it does not disappoint. If you get a chance take a look from the backside of the arch with the beach.
No matter how you get here it's sure to please. Our small boat was out about 9 am before things became too busy and the light too strong. Lovely!
Nice way to greet visitors with a view like this. Easily recognizable from the deck of a cruise ship and prettier up close.
As we went with Cabo Trek, they stopped and took our picture. This is a fascinating must see landscape.
Early in the morning and take your own snorkeling great private trip. Make sure you don't get to deep. Locals said to have seen sharks

There is always an experience you have to do when visit a place. For me it here. Don’t get me wrong, it was busy with lots of others boats but worth the trip. You have many options to see and explore it. We visited El Arco through the Caborey. It was a sunset cruise with food,
No pictures will ever do it justice. First time from a Cruise ship... butvup close is best. Gets a bit choppy but just move w d ocean 🐋

A beautiful spot to see via glass bottom boat. Spend time at Lover's Beach too or take a cruise at sunset!

The visit was a couple of times. I was at this place and area on the Whale watch tour, and for scuba diving. It is a beautiful area, just like all the pictures that you see. It can get busy with boats at times, but that is expected. Watch for water taxi prices and tours,
Must visit place is awesome, fish swims around you , is awesome. Easy to get there taxi charge $100 pesos each, dont let them rip you off
Had an amazing time on a Jazz and Wine cruise in Cabo San Lucas. As a bonus, had an opportunity to see two whales during the cruise.
Your trip will not be complete if you do not make a trip to see the Arch. We took it in over a sunset cruise which was a great way to get pics and enjoy the area.
You really cannot come to Cabo San Lucas and not go out to the iconic Lands End. Always a fun trip and you can do it with any number of boating options.
There are many many boats at the harbour that will take you to the arco.The boat ride is short and the views are gorgeous. Definitely worth a look.

It is well know to come here on a tour day or night. You have to come and know the places everyone talks about El Arco Cabos! I came during day got off the boat. Return on a night tour around El Arco.

We returned to Cabo San Lucas, this time by cruise ship. As such our first site we see is th is impressive Ell Arco de Cabo San Lucas. There are various tourist boats that one can also take to get a closer view when visiting the area.
If your entering or leaving, make sure you get as close as safe to take in the view and hear the waves. Both sides are different so make the extra trip

I suggest going on a sunset cruise. There are several. You can go on a rough Boose cruise, a Jazz and wine cruise or the Caboray. It depends on what kind of cruise you are looking for. The wine and Jazz cruise is nice and if there is enough wind, they open up the sails on the
El Arco is definitely worth a visit. It is special to be at the point where the Pacific ocean meets the Sea of Cortez. Go by boat or kayak - its a great experience

Boat cruise ride around El Arco was amazing. Beautiful location, short ride from the hotel. Worth the time and money to spend a few hours touring around the area. Very relaxing and definitely one of a kind experience! Took many photos to relive the great memories. Best of all
Saw the arch, good dinner, lots of alcohol and a close up of 2 whales! Good tequila tasting and a great bus guide.

The very first day we were in Cabos San Lucas...just walking and the captain of Luna Glass Boat invited to join him to Los Arcos. We sad yes!!! We had been before, but this time it was quieter, only 3 couples...We got very close and had a fantastic time!!!

The Arch at Cabo Lands End I heard was the most photographed in the world. Even if not true it is always beautiful. If you are on a cruise ship and on the port side of the ship be on deck or on your balcony when your ship approaches Cabo. You will get great shots of the arch

You cannot miss seeing Los Arcos, if you get up early in the morning, it's one wonder of the world to view. Get a Panga and head over there, it's another planet. Beautiful, but very dangerous if you don't follow boating, diving or fishing rules. Respect the waters and beach,

It was very difficult to get on and off the boat as the Medino Beach has very strong waves. I had to have about 4 or 5 people help me on and off. However, once on the boat, it was amazing! I saw many colorful fish, seals on the rocks, pelicans in the water, and the area where
My family enjoyed this tour and spending time at lovers beach. You have to bring your own food/snacks.

This is a trip to one of Cabo San Lucas' key attractions. A short boat ride out of the marina, past the rocks and resident sea-lions before jumping off at Lovers beach. Waves and surge can be big as this is where the Pacific and Sea of Cortes meet. You can walk over the sand to

This is an amazing place to see, I was so impressed. This is a must. In La Marina you can pay 150 Mexican pesos for a maybe short trip and they leave you in a beach, could be playa del amor or playa del divorcio (I recommend playa del amor, the waves are less strong). This is a

We were visiting Los Cabos famous arch, lovers and divorce beach for a day. That was a great trip including snorkeling, seals and pelicans watch. Take some drinks and food with you, because there you cant really get anything and you dont need to rush back to the marina. Its

Our extended family booked a 3-hour pontoon boat snorkeling tour, and it exceeded our expectations. The boat was very comfortable, with leather seats and plenty of room. The captain and the guide were friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable and took us to see the top sights

We did this as part of our Nexus / Novo two city and glass bottom boat tour This is a definite must do when in Cabo San Lucas I would suggest the snorkelling tour as you will want to see the beaches up close Snorkelling looked interesting
Marine lifeis thriving amongst this natural beauty. Saw multiple sea lions, pelicans and even a whale!

Came at Cabo San Lucas last week. The arch is a must see if you are travelling here. Such a beautiful location and picture opportunity as well. There are plenty of cheap tours that will bring you right at the arch. You will not regret!

Had an amazing time in Cabo for 10 days. 6 of us stayed in Riu Palace and had access to other 2 resorts next door. Weather 31 and sunny every day. Loved the boat ride from Marina to Lovers Beach/arch. Only pd $12 US pp. Had little tour and then able to be dropped off at beaches

our tour was just amazing, we took many photos and enjoyed every second of our visit. we landed for two hours in the Love & Divorce beaches and enjoy the sun and a peaceful 2 hours. it is just breath-taken to be able to be enjoy all the beautiful scenery.

We got to see the beautiful arch on two occasions, once when we went on the Cabo Escape Sunset Cruise, and again when we hired a water taxi to go to Lover's Beach. On both occasions, we saw the arch from both the Sea of Cortes side and from the Pacific Ocean side. The views

Good value for money worked out about £18/£20 each if you go with scuba caribe who are on site of the Hotel on the beach ,they pick you up and drop you off at the hotel
Awesome, what I loved about this tour was the history you received as well as the captain of the boat getting close enough for you to get good pictures. So beautiful nature! A absolutely MUST SEE!!!

we saw it from a tour boat, one can take a simple ride out to the arches for about $10US pp, or something more involved as we did as stated iconic site, if you're here you will want to see it, especially up close

Gorgeous! Sea lions hanging out on the rocks! Great picture spot. Amazing formations. Loved this very much!
Must see when in Cabo. We chartered a private tour boat with “Rogers tours” to come see the Arco. There are many ways to see this spot but I enjoyed our route.
If you visit Cabo, you should really see the arch. The arch is beautiful, I did a glass bottom boat and snorkeling combo (70 us) and it was great. Saw 3 humpback whales on the return trip
Excellent glass bottom boat ride to the Arch with Juan. Safe, friendly and beautiful. Worth $. No worries!
We went on the glass bottom to see the arch. It's a must see. It's absolutely beautiful. Theres also a beach there that you can go on, if you can find a boat to drop you off.
We loved the dinner cruise, the food was good and the staff was outstanding, my family and I loved the dance activities. I recommend ECO CAT.
Cruise around points of interest and a great dinner and entertainment. Crew was extremely helpful and kept the Tequila Sunrises flowing. Dancing and just having a ball.
The view is unbelievable. It is truly Mexico in one photograph. Sunset here is unlike anywhere else I've ever seen

Got to tour around the arch as part of a private sunset dinner cruise my wife and I took last month. Breathtaking, both from the bay side and the Pacific Ocean side! Watching the sea lions laying on the rocks just to the South was a treat!
The arch is a beautiful natural wonder. There are lots of options to get there from downtown Cabo; boats, catamarans, or even kayaks.

You need to rent a boat to go and visit the arch. You have many options at the marina. We went at the afternoon but it seems at the lat afternoon is the best hour. You can see sea lions as well in the marina.
The arch is beautiful! Recommend both lovers beach and divorce beach! Fun at both locations for sure!

We visited the Arch by glass bottom boat twice on 2 different excursions. The formations here are amazing. The Arch, Scoobie Doo, Lover's and Divorce Beach as well as Pirate Cave. The snorkeling here was good. A wide variety of fish including millions of sardines that

This is one of the many "tourist" junkets that you will be sold on your trip here. But it is still worth taking. Many different varieties and no doubt prices will be available so be aware of that. It is a lovely trip for seeing the coastline and development of Cabo San Lucas

We took a cruise and dinner to see El Arco , the tour last two hours just zigzagging the bay , pretty much seeing the same thing over and over The live band was really good but unfortunately the people on board were or either to old or to bore to dance The shows were very nice

Signed up for this tour at our Hotel and was transported to Cabo to get on the sailboat for a Sunset cruise of the Arches. Some food was supplied to include beverages, not a booze cruise. Was nice to see up close and around during the Sunset.
The views were spectacular the people were great very friendly and accommodating. Took in sailing and snorkeling amazing experience.
Everyone should take advantage of seeing the arch in cabo. Catch it with a water taxi or glass bottom boat or snorkel.

I have to laugh at the different places the locals get us to see and pay for. This arch is nice. There are more sight seeing boats than sea gulls. The boat bring you around the arch and you can see through it. They also name the beaches around the arch. Lover's beach
A trip to Cabo is not complete unless you take a trip out to the arch. We took a sunset cruise out and around lands end... it was a very nice trip.
This is a special place for us as we met and where married in Cabo. Enjoy the pictures of this romantic epic location.
Saw this while on a boat tour. And to think there was sand there before the last hurricane? Amazing creation and then to think how the forced of nature change it with time. Beautiful sight!
An absolutely amazing experience with breathtaking views. Clear water perfect for snorkeling and swimming.
Took a dinner Fajita sunset cruise. Beautiful Sunset, but a little too "wild" for my taste. More of a booze cruise. Still enjoyed it though.

We booked the CaboEscape Fajita Sunset cruise and was not disappointed! We usually aren’t into these kinds of “booze cruise” things but thought it would be a great way to see the Arch at sunset - what a blast! The views of the arch were amazing and there were lots of

Cmon, how often are you going to be that close to something unique like this? It costs very little to have a water taxi take you out to look at the rock formations up close, the pretty little beaches, and the small sea lion colony. Stick a fork in your wallet and have a fun

Unforgettable sight! At the junction of the Pacific and sea of Cortez, these cliffs are breathtaking. Warm waters are full of marine life and there are some great beaches nearby. Must visit! Took Rancho Tours boat ride here and it was perfect.

I took a glass bottom boat to the arch and stayed at the beach for about 90 minutes. One of the few highlights on this otherwise tacky town. Don't get me wrong, Cabo has so much natural beauty but the tourist area is tacky as hell and is overrun with Americans.

We would pass by this beautiful site every morning and afternoon. It is well worth seeing. The water is clean and changes from a deep blue to a greenish color. Go see it

This is such a beautiful place to go. The water is so many different shades of blue and its amazing to see them. The cruise out to the arch is so calming and fresh. It's definitely a sight that you should get a close view and many pictures of it.
when you visited the arc during our dive trip with dive cabo. how are you get there, go see it. It is a spectacular sight
Very Romantic place, full of under the sea life... Glass bottom boats are able to show it! Or scuba diving! we were there 2 times with pirate boats and regular boat...Nice for photo sessions...

There are numerous sunset boat cruises available to see the "Hole In The Rock" every evening. We have rented jet skis to see it also. Keep the jet ski moving ever so slightly to avoid getting dumped in the water. Several times each year you can see a small beach that runs
Where the Sea of Cortez meets the Pacific Ocean. Lots of fish, pelicans and seals to be seen. Well worth the $20 boat ride.

This was a reasonable excursion from Villa del Palmar beach. All 12 of us had our private tour. The tour was informative. It was interesting to hear the guide point out the dinosaur drinking water from the sculptures and other characters. We brought our tequilla on the boat
It is an amazing rock formation that is completely Breath Taking.... one can appreciate this wonder from both sides, the Sea of Cortez and the Pacific Ocean.
Amazing to see this iconic landmark. You can only get there by boat and you will see Pelican's Rock and the colony of sealions. Great opportunity to snorkle there too.

Incredible view from the sunset boat cruise we took! I’ve been coming to Cabo for years and only seen it able to be walked under 2 times, what an experience let me tell ya!! A must see when in Cabo San Lucas
We enjoyed viewing El Arco. It was fun going on a small 'water taxi' out to it to see it up close. The waves crashing in were awesome.
Took a boat ride to view Lovers beach, honeymoon beach and divorce beach as well as the arch of Cabo. So BEAUTIFUL!😍
The rock formations, the arch, glass bottom boat tour, sea lions and sea turtles all made our trip a great memorable one!!!!
I have seen El Arco twice. Once was on a dinner sunset cruise and the other was a kayak trip. Both times it was breathtaking. A definite must see.

The view of the Arch is spectacular. I viewed the Arch from a boat (water taxi and from the sunset dinner cruise) and from the small plane. It was an awesome view when the sun is setting and enjoying a nice drink of tequila.
My family and I took a sunset dinner cruise to see this and the view was absolutely beautiful. There were sea lions hanging out on the adjacent rocks which added to the ambiance.
Pictures do not do the arch justice. Take the time to at least take a water taxi, glass bottom boat, or better yet, a sunset sail. Plenty of fish, sea lions, and pelicans to see.

If you went to Los Cabos and didn’t made it to the arch , you’ve never been there ! You gotta check it out !
Your trip to Cabo would not be complete without seeing the arch. Just go to the marina and select any water taxi to take you to and from the arch. Use your negotiating skills to get your best deal.

Got an up close view of the beautiful Cabo Arch. It's worth the boat ride to go out there and take pictures of this beautiful area. Any cruise you take whether it's a sunset cruise or the pirate ship will take you by the iconic Arch.

If you take a boat tour around El Arco, hopefully you will be there during sunset. The view makes for wonderful photo ops. The sunset colors through the arc and around the other formations are art-worthy. I highly recommend taking a trip out to see El Arco close-up!
Find one of the many boat trips around the Arch. You will not be disappointed. Sunset is always the best time.
Words cannot describe the first time you see it up close. Magnificent.. .. ... From the crashing waves to the playful seals not to be missed !
