This rock formation is stunning, simple amazing how mother nature sculpted the rock and made this beautiful sculpture. If you don't have much time you can take a water Taxi at the Marina and will take you there to take the iconic picture sightsee some other formation and the Sea
A must visit when in Cabo! Just beautiful, pictures do not do the view and beauty justice. We chartered a boat and stopped to snorkel at Pelican Rock, awesome experience, I highly recommend it

Had a great breakfast cruise to lands end & whale watching. The food was excellent - prepared fresh on the boat. Our captain did a good job of trying to get us close to the whales. Lands end is beautiful. Take lots of pictures!!
got to go the arch again and lovely like always got to see the colorful fishes and the whales >>>> a little bit cold but worth the trip
El arco it’s beautiful and in the morning there are a few trips so you can take pictures easily. It’s a most.
Ramon and Efrain were awesome tour guides with lots of great history of the area that they shared with us. Also very accommodating in helping us get the perfect picture of the Arco.
A must see when here. You can rent a water taxi to take you too Lovers beach so you can enjoy the Arc all day.

Each time past is different. The shapes and colors of the sea, sand, rocks, sun, clouds and wildlife constantly change and creating new and beautiful scenes. We traveled past the Arch and rock formations each and every trip we took by boat. To go fishing, whale watching, and for

We use the water taxis (glass bottom boats) to see the arches and outer beaches but also to get to the Marina area. Best prices and service to what you want on the non-Cruise ship (Tues & W) days. If you just want a ride to and from town, ask for that service at a reduced rate.

Los Arcos, the iconic rocks marking the furthest extension of land into the Sea of Cortes, is an absolute must. There are numerous water taxi available to take you from the Marina out too the rocks. Most have glad bottoms, so you can see the beautiful fish along the reef. You
A must see...Pictures don't do "El Arco" justice. No trip to Cabo is complete without getting on the water and cruising to El Arco.
We took the short one hour boat ride. Just right if you don't want to spend the day on the water. Saw the arch and cool beaches and up close with fish and sea lions. Really a fun quick ride.

Took a glass bottom boat out to the arch for a short tour. It was great to see and very beautiful. We saw some whales and sea lions. They dropped us at Lovers beach for about an hour where we snorkeled and swam in the ocean.
The arc/Land's End is worth seeing once. Sea lions entertaining. I've seen it on multiple whale watching trips and once, when there was more to Lover's Beach, via glass bottom boat.

We actually stayed at Villa Del Palmar resort but visited El Arco during our stay and found it to be nicer and much more quiet than our resort. We had lunch on their “ship”, we found the shrimp stuffed avocado and quesadillas to be very tasty and service really good. NOTE: there
This iconic site was a must see on our trip. I was absolutely thrilled with seeing it firsthand. The Sea Lions were an added bonus.

We (my Sr mom and I) took a 50min water taxi out to the geologically significant rock formations past the marina in Los Cabos (which means "the capes" in English). The pilot took us up close to the Pacific Eye- a hole in the rocks peeking to the Pacific side and often burbling

A top attraction while in Cabo. You must see the Arch/Lands End. We actually took a boat tour past all the rocks/arch formations. I personally don’t care for boats and being on the water but we used SunRider Tours and I honestly couldn’t recommend them more! Made the experience

Just grab a little water taxi on the beach in front of Breathless for $10usd/pp and they will take you around the arc. It is just gorgeous - the rock formations are awe-inspiring! You won’t be disappointed!

Absolutely beautiful place. Must see. I remember when the Love Boat was on television and they would stop here. Cabo San Lucas arches are probably one of the most recognizable land marks in the world, but if you haven't seen them in person you haven't really seen them. And at

We didn't want to do the tour of the Rock with many people. this tour is PERFECT! there were only about 12 on the boat which made it a bit more intimate and you get personal attention from the 2 crew members. we had a glass bottom boat and could see the different types of fish

A beautiful landmark that is a must see when going to Cabo! Many of the excursions you do will go by and explain this area so I would not get an excursion that is focused solely on only this. If you do however, I would look for a glass bottom boat where the operator cleans the

Where the Pacific Ocean meets the Sea of Cortez. We got on a water taxi and spent a few hours at Lovers Beach. Very quaint and small sandy beach. Great swimming and snorkeling. Make sure to take your garbage back with you.
Went here twice for whale watching and a sunset cruise. It's a very beautiful area. Saw lots of whales and sea lions sunning and swimming alongside the boat.

Best Sunset ever! booked 1 day prior to departure we had went out a day befor to downtown cabo all afternoon - night we had walked in the afternoon and we booked a sunset cruise with an opc there at the marina and that night went out and ejoyed cabos nightlife! the next day we
a very nice sunset cruise with dinner and open bar to view the arch as well as look for humpbacks. nice way to get out of the resort for a few hours. also whale shark diving was cancelled.

Los Cabos would not be the same without at least visiting this landmark. Nature-has provides a reason to visit. Visit from the water and pay attention to the authorities. Parts of the location are sometimes dangerous because of weather and tides. Especially onbthe Pacific dide.

Along with another couple I took a day exercion with my husband to el arco cruise and scenic view on the caborey. We all thoroughly enjoyed the boat and the scenic view was truly breathtaking. I wish they had given us at least another hour or more. We had purchased this

We were in Mexico with a group of 13 friends. We rented a boat, the Natalia, and took a tour of lovers Beach & Lands End. It was a great way to spend an hour and everybody who visits going to Cabo San Lucas should do this.

Very scenic and cool, but really not worth paying for on its own unless you get a really cheap excursion. We used Cabo Adventures for a couple of other excursions and they gave us a free whale watching tour that drove right by the Arch and showed us the beaches and sea lions
So cheap if you go find someone off the beach. We did not get deals through the hotel but everyone on the beach selling stuff was more than accommodating so try your luck!
Beautiful natural monument worth a visit to see up close in boat trip. Great photo opportunities and memorable scenery

The Oceanus yacht sunset cruise was very fun and took us to a sightseeing tour that started at the marina and headed to Los Arcos. It continued on the Pacific side of Cabo viewing the beautiful homes on the hills.

Grabbed a water taxi from Medano Beach out there and were very glad we did. Yes, it is super touristy but it is very cool. The rock formations are fascinating and our guide did his best to answer our questions about them as we went all around Lands End. They also dropped us

You can’t visit Cabo and not visit the Arch! Nature’s beauty can be appreciated while in a sunset cruise, snorkeling tour or just a quick tour in a glass bottom boat... plus you can see whales from Dec-March ;)

We bargained for $9 a person and are surprised when another family came aboard for $35 each, including snorkeling. The family never went snorkeling because the boat wanted to leave them snorkeling alone for an hour. In the end, the captain was angry at all of us for our
Trip round the bay to see pelicans and sea lions. Much better trips in Peru. Diesel smell did not help. Very rough. Not worth bother IMHO

We went to see the world famous arch along the booze cruise and it was worth every penny we got to view the arch from all angles well partying on a huge boat. It was also cool to see the sunset. If you’re in Cabo you have to experience this.

The best way to see this is rent a boat privately. You have options to stay longer and even stop on Lovers or Divorce beach. I highly recommend Esperanza Tours. You can also bring your dog on the boat. We rented a glass bottom boat where we can saw parrot fishes swimming near
This was awesome ! The dudes driving the boats are better than NYC taxi drivers. I absolutely loved this quick trip to lands end. If you don’t do this, did you even go to Cabo?
A must see! Took a boat tour to see The arch, along with Lover's beach and everything else and I have to admit, it was breathtaking.
Take the boat tour to these rocks with beaches and lots of fish. Costs 300 peso for 45 minutes. Well worth it.

When you go to Cabo, you gotta see the arch. The most fun way is on a smooth ocean day, take a kayaking and snorkeling trip. The Arch, Lovers Beach, Divorce Beach on the opposite side, Seal Island, and the snorkeling were great! We loved it! I took GREAT pictures but I should

Dramatic formations at Lands End, its worth seeing up close. Also had the chance to scuba dive at the base of Lands End during our visit later in the week.

The Arch is a must go and see. When we went, apparently it was one of the rare times when you could walk under the arch. Most of the time, the tide is too high and water covers the sand below. Locals said it happens about every 4or 5 years.

Of course you have to take a boat out to Land's End if you are in Cabo. Such a spectacular site. Many options from snorkeling, whale watching, sunrise, sunset sales. Operators all seem quite competent and honed given the competition for business.

Take one of the many small boats out to Los Arcos.. I have been here a number of times and never bothered but it's well worth the time. The sea lions are always interesting and the small boats can really get you in close to the swells by the point and it's exhilarating!

A great trip and it was great that we could see "The Arco". We were told that when the water is high it is impossible to have a great view of it. So, if you are in Cabo and the weather is great, go for it.
Nothing to say except it's a must see Everytime I go. Don't leave Cabo without taking a ride out to see it up close. Breathtaking beyond words.

Thank you Cabos Adventure and Alexi for a great informative tour of the rock formations, Sea of Cortez and smooth sailing! We saw two turtles during this tour, amazing time spent on the water. Watch it on Play&EatwithUs on YouTube.

What a fun time for all. Several brides to be were celebrating and the staff was amazing. Foodcwas delicious
GREAT TOUR GUIDE (DENNIS) AND HELPERS. Glassblowing factory tour, tequila tasting tour and other things. Nice drive along the Corridor to/from San Jose del Cabo and shopping there.

I was not expecting much but the boat tour that I took of the arch was one of the best things I did in Mexico. We got to see not only the natural stone formation itself, but also, many pelicans, tropical fish, and seal-like animals that were perfectly posed upon prominent rocks
Awesome natural place! The experience is amazing specially when you think that it could disappear if the sea rises
We used Cabo Sailing and it was great! A'Leal and Humberto were great! There were 4 of us and we had our own boat! The margaritas and fresh guacamole were a treat!
Just amazing such natural beauty. Definitely must see if your in Cabo really need to take the boat tour and experience it up close.

The views at El Arco are beyond stunning! The color of the water will take your beath away. The light breezes will lull you into a state of total relaxation. The water on the Pacific side can be rough so hold on to your seat! A definite must-do while in Los Cabos!

You take a glass bottom boat and just enjoy your time. Take a camera and a lot of photos. If you get a cool boat driver, he will let you swim.

We did not want to spend 2,3 or more hours on a boat. Wandered down to the beach and found a guy returning a couple to the shore. We asked if he would take us to see the arch, told him we did not want a long ride. When we asked the price, he said $22 per person. I offered
This was a perfect representation of the people of Mexico and the pride they share for their country. The boat was safe, crew well versed in the history and the cost was so perfect!

I have never been to Cabo, but I would strongly recommend doing this, the scenery is just breath taking and the crew made sure you all get pictures to take home of the rock formations and the beach. Very informative and relaxing!

Went tho The Arch in a private yatch excursion Plenty options at the marina, with different boats an prices Amazing experience to be that close to the end of mainland till the last stone in front of the arch with a small sand beach (once every 10 years) Unfortunatelly we where

Did this tour with family of 4 (2 kids under 9yrs) Informative and enjoyed by all. Not to long roughly ~ 3 hours in total. Transportation is flexible to allow time after the boat ride to walk the market place.

We took glass bottom boat out to Los Arcos a couple days ago. Been there before, but this trip kicked it up a notch! Saw a bunch of colorful fish under the boat, plus some sea lions swimming alongside. The boat took in real close to view caves, including one where the Pacific

This is a must do the trip to Cabo. What we did I know there were a plethora of costs in terms of how exactly you want to do experience your trip to lands end. We were considering a private boat which can cost, depending on the amount of people anywhere from $500-$1000 with
Our guide Oliver took our group all over the land’s end area, giving some history and trivia. We loved this part of the tour!

A must see if you are out for a tour. The arch of Cabo San Lucas, is a magnificent rock formation at the southern tip of Cabo San Lucas as you are entering the harbor. Watch for the sea lions that seem to be everywhere.

I have literally nothing negative to say about our stay at this facility. The beach was immaculate, although the water was closed due to rip tides, the rooms were cleaned daily and the service was excellent. It was wonderful to sleep with our door open and listen to the waves.
It’s a must in Cabo! Lots of tours to the arch. Low season you should be paying under $200 peso per person.
We took a boat ride to the archo! Absolutely loved it so worth it! This is a must if you are in Cabo!

Pick up from hotel, guided boat charter from Cabo San Lucas marina to el Arco, tequila tasting, glass blowing demonstration, lunch in San Jose del Cabo, and about an hour of free time to shop after tequila tasting and lunch. Guide Marcos was excellent and boat captain Charlie

We saw this from the shore and just had to see it, and so we found a boat to ferry us there. The "guide" made a big deal of the fact that on one side was the Gulf of California and on the other was the Pacific. I frankly could not see the difference, but I'm still glad we went.

We traveled with a toddler, so the day for our boat tour to El Arco was the most exciting excursion we booked. We didn't snorkel. The water was choppy and there were a lot of boat traffic, but we did see people from other boat tours snorkeling in the water. We were able to see
This is a must see on! So schedule a boat tour to visit the land marks. It’s well worth it and the tour guides are knowledgeable

This place is a must see , the sea lions and the fish are just a small part of this. This is just a must see to experience to see for yourself the waters are a bit choppy but worth the trip to see where the two seas divide
A must see by boat. A natural beautiful piece of our planet. Cheap too if you use a small boat that you find alone the beach there.

When you come to Cabo,you must see Lands End -The Arch. I recommend taking a glass bottom boat for about $15 for a 45 minute trip around the arch. Will get to see some sea lions and great rock formations like Neptune’s finger and of course the Arch.

The Arches are a classic Cabo attraction but definitely watch out for high surf. We are beach people, very comfortable in the water and the warning of rough surf is strong. If you have notions of your Feet in the ocean as you stroll down Lovers beach - you may be disappointed.

The most economical way to see the Arco is by water taxi. If you paid more than US$20 person, you paid too much. Try to book your taxi from your concierge at your hotel. If you book from one of the taxi peddlers off the marina at Cabos San Lucas, negotiate hard to get it back to
Great for kids and families! A little wild but still very entertaining! The costumes could be a bit more realistic but overall it was fun! Dancing on the boat was the Best part!
El Arco located at the meeting point of Pacific Ocean and the Sea of Cortez has scenic, fantastic rocky cliffs. Worth visiting with the glass bottom boat tour.
Definitely a once tome experience, have to get it off your bucket list. Spectacular natural views, super friendly people, fun* Too crowded but worth. Nicer boat transportation will help.
Such a spectacular site. I would highly recommend going during sunset. The sunset cruises are amazing.

What an experience to behold up close and personal where to sea of Cortez meets the Pacific Ocean. I totally enjoyed it and our tour guides with Rancho tours were excellent. I highly recommend this trip for anyone visiting Cabo

We took a tour to see the arch. It was cery beautiful. Rhe waters are also beautiful and very blue. I didnt like that the tour was very short and they promised to drop us off at the beach and come later and pick us up. That didnt happen, because they claimed the beach was
Cabo does not disappoint. Lots of great places to eat, shop and plenty of fishing charters available.
Doesn't get better than this, folks. Make sure you have a cocktail and are listing to tropical music. Just enjoy life with family or friends or both. Don't hold back. life is too short.
We had such a great time visiting the arch. The boat ride was fun and entertaining. There's so many beautiful sights.

A must see for your bucket list of places to visit! Breathtaking and wonderful Experience. I highly recommend taking sunset cruise as well as the personal glass bottom boat tour to get both perspectives

We skipped the large sunset cruises and opted for a glass-bottomed water taxi we picked up near the Rosè & Blanco resorts. The tickets were $10 each and the two drivers were great local guys. The name of the taxi to look for is Jose y Maria.

Some of gods beautiful creations. Breathtaking. I wish we hold have seen more wildlife. The rip current was too strong to stop and get out in lovers and divorce beach. Tour guide was ok. He gave us time at each key point to take pictures. Would do this over and over again. But

My family of 3 booked a private, 1 1/2 hr. tour w/Victor Manuel (owner), for the price of $30/person. (He said the tour is typically 1 hr., but we negotiated an extra 30 min., and glad we did.) His glass bottom boat is well maintained and it's obvious he takes pride in his
Beautiful and Amazing. We went around 6:00pm and took a boat from the Mango Deck! Our tour guide was awesome and told us so many stories about the history. Loved it.

We took the Land’s End tour and the name of our boat was the “New York”. The tour took us out as far as Divorce Beach and along the way our captain explained the natural landmarks as well as made sure we saw the beautiful fish and got the best pictures of Arch and the Ventana.
the beach is amazing, but the best part is the view getting there. Both lovers beach and widows beach offer pristine sandy beaches. Just don't swim at widows.

Absolutely worth visiting if you have time! El Arco is at the tip of the Baja Peninsula where the Pacific Ocean becomes the Sea of Cortez. My friends and I chartered a yacht to travel up the coast, but there are many ways to enjoy the Arch; visit the natural beauty of Playa
google:
We stopped at Lover’s Beach near El Arco for a pre-wedding day photo shoot. In love with this beach and the sunrise here. Can’t wait to visit again soon.

FYI Tide is strong, not for swimming, and can only get to during low tide times of the day. Be sure to away from the Divorce side too! 🙃❤️🌊
It was one of the best experiences I've ever had. Never imagined I'll be visiting this amazing place one day. Can't wait go back! 👏🏻
So beautiful! We even say a sea lion hitching a ride back into town on the back of a fishing boat! Worth the trip! Don’t swim!

text.wiki:
The Basilica of San Francisco in the city of La Paz, Bolivia, is a Catholic church under the advocation of Francis of Assisi. It is located in the center of the city, in the square that bears its name, Plaza San Francisco.
The building was built between 1743-1772 but its tower was built in the end of the 19th century.


== History ==
It was built between the sixteenth and eighteenth centuries in the so-called Andean Baroque style. Milestones in its history include:

In 1548, the Convent of San Francisco was founded along the Choqueyapu River by Fray Francisco de Morales.
In August 1549 the construction of the first Church of San Francisco began, which was concluded in 1581.
Between 1608 and 1612 the first church collapsed as a result of a snowfall of considerable proportions.
Between 1743 and 1744 the construction of the present church began.
In 1753, the closure and the roof of the church's dome were completed.
On April 23, 1758, it was consecrated.
In 1790, the carved façade is finished.
In 1885, the construction of its single tower began.
In 1948, it was declared a minor basilica.
Between 1950 and 1960, part of the convent was demolished and the atrium reconfigured.
Between 1965 and 2005, the church was restored, and the part of the convent remained was enabled as a museum.


== References ==


== Sources ==
ÁLVAREZ LÓPEZ, Rolando. CRONOLOGÍA de SEPTIEMBRE y OCTUBRE de 2010. Rev. Fuent. Cong., oct. 2010, vol.4, no.10, p. 76-80. ISSN 1997-4485. Consulted in www.revistasbolivianas.org.bo, in June, 2013.
Iglesias mostrarán su patrimonio arquitectónico en la “Noche Blanca”, published in El Diario, October, 19 of 2012, consulted in www.eldiario.net, in June, 2013.
Centro cultural Museo San Francisco, Official Web Site https://web.archive.org/web/20140102073422/http://www.museosanfranciscobolivia.com/

text.quote: Monumental 18th-century church featuring ornate carvings, panoramic rooftop views & guided tours.
trip: This is a beautiful church both exterior and interior. The tour of the Bell Tower was good as it offers views of the streets below. But the steps could be quite steep so have to be careful.

I'm not a big church-goer; more of an art and history buff. But I did enjoy my visit to this chuch and the grounds within. My volunteer(?) guide really helped the appreciation of the building and its history. We explored a few hidden nooks and crannies and even went up on the

The entry fee of 20 BOB is worth it. We had an informative guide take us through the museum, explaining the history of the Cathedral, paintings & St Francis along the way. The cloisters , garden & rooms we visited were very interesting & we got to go up onto the roof of the

A much visit attraction in La Paz. Such a beautiful church. The gilded alter is everything you would expect from a church this old. But please remember when you visit that it is a living and breathing church. Lots of Bolivians use it every day to pray. to see their display
Beautiful architectural monument. As you enter the building you will feel its grandeur and its unique peace that is so missed by many modern churches today.

A little difficult to walk round as I was there when there was a service on. Pars of the Cathedral are highly decorative and rather baroque in style. I always feel that these are too grand for the needs of religion. The glory of the church not a place for worship. Lovely facade

This is well worth a visit and I recommend a tour. The structure is fascinating as is the history of this residence. The roof tiles are incredible. Shaped on the thighs of the men working on the roof. Quite amazing.
It's a really impressive church. If you get a tour you'll appreciate it a lot more. If you get the chance go to the top of the bell tower for amazing views of the city
The church is nice and relatively big. It is located in the centre of La Paz, easily reachable on foot. Note that you are not allowed to take pictures inside, like in most churches in Bolivia.

This church and the history are amazing (and I'm not usually a huge church person when traveling). the tour was very cheap, and you get to know the history of the church and some of La Paz, and get to go on the roof for amazing views. I highly recommend taking the tour!

A beautiful old church with an always busy square artists, vendors, comedians, travelers, locals... everyone. Interesting place to relax with some fresh popcorn or coconut water while you take in the sites, sounds and smells of La Paz.

It's a nice cathedral and well worth stopping by if in the area. When we were there it seemed the hours were a little variable.
My wife and I had a great time in the Plaza del Armas area of Lapaz and visited this church, a wonderful experience. Very well preserved, and a local treasure for sure.

Even if you are not inside the structure and the history about it, is something that you can not forget from inside is so quiet and the smell of old church is unreal, the people preying and getting some spiritual connection is something that it's not so common to find. Special
Very impressive and thoughtfully build. Could walk in for free and enjoy the darkness and peace of this place. The place in front is very busy.

Nothing spectacular compared to some south American cathedrals or churches but still another good example

During the guided tour for about an hour & 15 minutes (a "compulsory one" but one where I was assigned a guide right away after entering without having to wait for other people), I did get to see: the "original remains" underneath seen through glass along the corridor on one
They did not offer the tour in English. Church is lovely and was very busy. The church is in San Francisco Square, which is full of tourists. Be careful of pick pockets.

nice museum and nice church visit. you can see the internal garden, some colonial paints and the roof of the church. very interesting the view of the church from the chorus. the tour is only in Spanish.
Five days in and around town. We did not have time to get into the church and / or the museum. We only saw the church from outside and all of its sculptures indigenous and not so sacred, we loved it.
The church is situated at the San Francisco Square, which is usually full of people, so be careful. The church itself is worth a visit, although it is quite lugubrious inside.

Now we avoid this square. Crowded, filthy, hard to walk on sidewalks because of the many vendor, and pick pockets. The food and stuff being sold is disgustingly dirty. Garbage is simply tossed on the street.

Another one of those ridiculous relics of the spanish invasion and suppression of a strong group of cultures. That aside, the building isamarelof constructin and architectural skills and definitely worth a visit.

Went here as part of an organised full day tour with Transturin. Beautiful Spanish style church in the middle of a very busy part of town. Lots of beautiful paintings inside. Worth a visit if in La Paz

It was a good place for some history about Bolivia and the construction of the most beautiful Church that I visited in Bolivia. The best part it's to feel the cold air around the back. The sad part is that we couldn't took some pictures of this beautiful place.

There is no charge just walk in. The church is extremely ornate with golden altars and paintings and statuary everywhere. It is a basilica and is, I believe, the oldest church in La Paz dating back to the middle of the 16th centuries. Founded by the Franciscan order. Next

The entrance fee is 15bs with a private guided tour (mandatory). The guide we had didn’t speak good enough English for us to understand the places and keep rushing us to the next spot. The museum and the church has quite a few different rooms and art gallery with brief
Really nice place. We paid 15bs and the guide was included. We got a lot of informations and felt comfortable with our authentic and nice guide.

This old church is a solid addition to the spirit of La Paz. While the outside is not especially compelling, the inside is highly ornate with many intricate golden carvings around pictures of holy persons. There was a mass in progress while I was there and I was impressed by the

Very nice inside architecture, also nice facade with a mix of indigenos and conqueror symbols. A bit tricky to visit on a Sunday as there are a lot of services. Even, worth to sit in, have a quite moment and look around the paintings, the gold foil decorated ornaments.
It's worth it to come in and see the church while it's open. Very pretty and huge. It's only open during Mass, so entering and sitting quietly recommend

Before going in the church we took a tour of the adjoining monastery. This was most interesting and very informative. We were shown models of the monastery both before and after alterations that cut the size of one of the quadrangle. You have to go on a tour to access the

This iconic church is a place of refuge from a crowded square in front of it. The wall-to-wall main altar is a riot of gold with an assortment of uniquely Bolivian santos. The church also boasts La Paz's best rooftop view which is only accessible if you buy a ticket to the

The architecture of this church is very interesting in that it combined religious Catholic statues alongside indigenous symbols. For a small charge you can walk up to the top of the bell tower for a great view of the city.
This was the starting point of our walking tour. The outside is more impressive than the interior. 10 mins inside was more than enough time to look round.

Nice and interesting for a short visit. Not so different from many other churches nd cathedrals in South America. Visit if within walking distance or a short cab ride, but not worth a long trip just to visit this place.

Interesting church to have a look at. It is useful to get a guide to help you understand and appreciate some of the intricacies and stories behind the building, as well as how the religious developed. Follow my #30somethinggapyear on Instagram @DatLoongJourney.

When you visit a foreign city, particularly like somewhere in Central or South America, there are a certain number of buildings to see - palaces, government buildings, cathedrals, etc. This is one of those in La Paz. St Francis seems to be a popular saint in this neck of the

Although you don't get to stand in the actual sanctuary, you do see a lot of the church and the surrounding buildings. Don't miss a visit to the bell tower and roof, if you don't mind narrow passageways.
The truth is difficult to contemplate in its entirety. The structure is made of stone and its history is worth remembering. If you are wearing a hat

Entry ticket included a guide, however you might get a uni student whose English is not very fluent. Interesting history of the cathedral and Franciscan monks. Worth climbing up the steep narrow staircase to the bell towers that offers nice view of surrounding and interesting

My husband and I visited the museum attached to the church as our first stop in La Paz. I can't remember the cost, but I know it was low. The rooms in the convent contained paintings and historical information (all in Spanish). There was no one to offer a tour in English,
well worth a stroll through to see the beautiful main and side altars. Was reverent and respectful as Mass was being celebrated. Obviously not as opulent as the churches and cathedrals in Europe.

We've taken an English tour of the church. The lady is an extremely experienced one who can manage to show us all important features of the church in a 40 minutes tour. However, the tour is a bit too short and we think it should take 1.5 hour to finish reading all those
The museum offers many rooms with detailed explanations of the history of the building & the Spanish influence in La Paz.
An artistic and architectural jewel. Incredible structure in the city. Good memories in adjacent stores.
Is one of the the principal churches in lapaz and a really enjoyed the place the museum is great! With guides, nice place to go for small history.

Originally founded in 1548 as the Convent of San Francisco followed by the church in 1549. Rebuilt in the mid 1750s the current baroque mestizo style church still stands and is a minor basilica. For a reasonable entrance fee, I received an individualized and comprehensive tour
The Church is beautiful, but when we went on a tour (20 b) we didn’t learn anything due to a stressed guide. But if you’re happy with just the interior- go!
Very interesting temple, outside amazing figure ( people , dragons animals , plants) old door , baroque style. Inside simply with many altars on the right and left sides. Photo - prohibited .

When we purchased tickets the staff said there would be English guide available, but when we walked up the stairs to start the tour, the staff there said there won't be any English guide. We walked by ourselves for a while until we bumped into a group of German tourists being

Sadly no photos but this building is very different to the cathedral which is mord in European style. The altar is gold replica. A huge full wall. There are statues and paintings in the native style and as our guide indicated represents a polytheistic belief system totally
This is well worth a visit, it has a lovely peaceful atmosphere and is a beautiful building. Shame about the hideous tower blocks all around it.

We visited Iglesias de San Francisco and were in absolute awe. Very well preserved and full of historic items thoughtful displayed. It was like a walk back through time. We would highly recommend visiting this Historic Site in La Paz. Well worth the time and money spent. Easy to

When I arrived at the church, early afternoon, I was told it was not open to the public until 6:00 PM. However, the church museum was open and admission is cheap. I was accompanied by an English speaking guide (although her command of English was rather rudimentary). I climbed
Very old rustic church, absolutely breathtaking on the inside well worth a visit. The day we visited it was decorated with hundreds of flowers!

I’m not catholic, but I can appreciate all the fantastic structures they have built and this one is impressive. Be warned, you are not supposed to take pictures inside . . . Oops! I didn’t see the sign until we were on our way out.
We passed by on the Saturday but it was closed only the museum was open, we did pass by again on Sunday and we were able to catch a mass which was very touching The church itself was very pretty.
Watch for pickpockets, but it is an interesting structure to visit. Lots of people congregate in the general area.

The outside is a reminder of Spanish colonialism and the architecture exquisite. It's not opulent like what I saw in Italy but it's massive and simple in structure. Inside it's a very much a daily practicing church where local devotees spend much time. Very very cool. It's

The church is not as impressive as its counterpart in Lima, but the tours provide great insights and take you up the bell tower. The guide we had spoke french, and was very knowledgeable. It is even amazing to see that there are still monks living there

We went for the Sunday mass, goes on every hour 7:00 to 11:00 AM. Unfortunately the guides only works Monday to Saturday, we will like to know more about the history. Even with aren't in too a mass worth the visit to see the Spanish conquers power.

It's a toss up as to whether the cathedral of the San Francisco church is the more stunning highlight of La Paz. The SF church is more accessible in terms of opening times, but photography is completely forbidden inside. The architecture isn't as impressive as the cathedral, but

Visting the church after 1600 is free and one can take a leisurely look around the stunning interior bearing in mind that photographs are strictly prohibited. The craftsmanship and dedication that has created the carvings and facade are staggeringly good. To view the monastery

This is arguably the most famous Plaza in La Paz. It's nice, but not impressive when compared to many of the famous plazas of the world. I certainly would not go out of my way to visit this place. But if you're in La Paz and have some free time, it's probably worth stopping
Once you enter to the Musuem you start to like it, the guide was very nice and helpfull!!! The paintings are beautiful!!!
The tour is good, and they have tour guides that do it in English. A tour of about 30 minutes. A little expensive bit worth it if you don't mind being bossed around for that length of time.
If you're staying near the church of San Francisco this is a good place to plan your day after breakfast while people watching.

I usually don't go to churches but I was there with my father and, beside he goes to church, we needed a place to rest! Lol We got there at the end of the Sunday worship and it was nice. They had a choir and people were singing and actively participating. I was raised as
Went in to church on a Sunday as it was the only day it was open while I was in town, managed to attend mass which was interesting in itself
The church is beautiful and worth a visit. The city square there is very popular. The mime clown is fun, as well as the Michael Jackson impersonator. Lots of actives and vendors. Great area.
You can't miss this church; it is the epicenter of the city. Lots of people and activity. Church is unique example of baroque mestizo style.
Nice old church that seemed to be the center of local activity. There are lots of vendors in the area
Unusual church blending the county's cultural traditions both inside and out but especially on the façade. If not to everyone's taste, full of interest and well worth a brief visit.

We enjoyed an English speaking guided tour through this incredibly historical building and got a nice view of the main square. The tour takes you through tight stairways and if you're lucky, to the script. Fantastic way to spend an hour.
Good way to spend about hour our guide juan alegandro made the tour very interesting and was free as part of the entry fee worth a visit

The Church can be visited by simply entering it, when it is open, but the adjacent museum enables the visitor to see its Franciscan Convent as well as the Bell Tower and various other nooks of the complex. The Mestizo Baroque architecture is of special interest

We really enjoyed this tour of the cathedral. The church is very old and since it was built clergy have lived here (still do). There and a few rooms where you really sense how it might have been to live here 300 years ago - and how oppressive the colonial morality was. We had

The building is a real gem. My only complaint is that you can only wander around as part of a guided tour, and our guide pushed us through at a brisk pace. I would have liked to take more time. I presume the tour is due to the meandering nature of the building. Parts are closed

The church is beautiful inside and out, it was very touching to be there during a mass and hear the voices raised in song filling the space, I'd go back to lion around more as I didn't like to during worship. The museum however is a disappointment - it costs 20bol to get in, a

The english guide on the museum.. Oh dear lord! Well, he didn't speak good English, I didn't mind that but he was so scared and embarrassed about that so he practically ran the place through and on the way just pointed up the objects and said a few words about them. The

The museum and the church are definitely worth a visit. The church is not accesible at all times of the day but if it's open it's worth a visit to see the beautiful altar and have a look at the crypts.

Located at the crossing of Sagarnaga and Murillo streets, in the back of the plaza with the same name, Iglesia de San Francisco is perhaps the oldest in the country. Construction started in 1548, before the founding of the city of La Paz, it then collapsed in 1612 and built
Well worth the visit. It's a beautiful church measuring up to those in Europe. The detailing on both the interior and exterior is incredible
Make your way here and then head off up the many laneways and explore the old City . The Church has lots of activity outside as well as the usual views inside

The architrcture is a combination of european and indiginous...so it is a beautiful unique church...no doubt But whats more excited are activities at the front...such as chess tables and street concert

One of the Most Important buildings in La Paz and a unique architecture and facade-decoration! Note the floral motives and the inca-faces there! And never forget to say a prayer for the Peoples of Bolivia!

This is a historic church built upon the peace between the rich spaniards and mestizos and the poor indigens The church is nice and classical; however it has been partially restored and in the process some of the charm went away to be replaced by glitterness
This is a really lovely church in the middle of crazy and busy La Paz - worth a visit even if you're not catholic or religious.

The monastery is interesting to visit and there is a nice view from the roof and bell towers. The guided tour provided only basic information and was only in Spanish though they do have alternate tours in English. The information delivered was pretty basic though, and provided
Nice church on a busy square where everyone tries to sell anything. Very close to the touristic Sganaga street.

Me and my friend are Australian and we visited this church today and not only did Daniel fill us with knowledge we had a good laugh together highly recommend for a fantastic experience! Muchas gracias Daniel & San Francisco!! Two proper legends
Beautiful building and a lovely town square adjacent. Exterior architecture is stunning, the solemn dark interior is incredibly interesting. Worth a 30 minute stop.
Cool place to visit, I must for all those visiting La Paz. Here you will see the San Francisco Church, loved the architecture of this church with Mestizo and Baroque influences.
A busy square where everyone collects. Watch your valuables. Church is old and great to take photos of.

You won't believe there is a place hidden in the middle of such trafic noise. San Francisco Church and Museum is worth to visit. There are guided tours and is cheap. You can visit the church and museum just in 30 minutes and climb until the bell tower to enjoy a beautifull
La Paz' oldest church and convent, if I'm not mistaken. Beautiful mestizo decorations on the front and the altar. Also have a look at the museum and the rooftop walk is not to be missed.
Don't miss this attraction. Take your time in the church. The inside of the church might be frightening to young children. My son did find the decorations scary but this is a must see in La Paz.
What a fantastic example of baroque in America. The altares and pulpits are beautiful! You should not miss this place!
It is a gorgeous Church, the architecture and design is very intriguing and appeals to all. The only thing is that on week days they open at 4;00PM, but other than than, well worth it

The best way to see the church is taking the museum tour. The church is more than just a church it's a convent. In old times it used to be a larger convent to which lay people where not allowed.. Now you can see parts of it. The climb to the roof is worth it! Enjoy

For 20Bs you get a guided tour in either English or Spanish, this lasts approx 45 mins so good for teenagers with a short attention span! You get to see around the monastery and the highlight (literally) would be the view from the church rooftop overlooking the city. The access

Besides the church, the huge space in front is a central gathering for many events in the city. In fact, the entire time we stayed here, every night there was a band playing and the plaza is so crowded. Back to the church, it is located in the Sagarnaga area. The

Tours are available every day of the week besides Sunday for 20 Bs. This grants you entrance and also a tour guide. I went alone, and they didn't even make me wait. I got a personal tour. They offer English and Spanish (maybe others but those were the only ones they offered me).
Great spot to be at. The markets start from here, the mall is across the street and the street vendors...we'll some of the best in La Paz.

Located west of El Prado. Founded in 1548. The facade is decorated with stone carvings of chirimoyas, pinecones and tropical birds. It is just a lovely church and when you go inside you can feel at peace and get the feel of how many Bolivians are devoted Catholics.

The church was certainly built on a grand scale and while the Italian marble flooring is opulent the rest is not as ornate as other churches such as in Cusco etc. It's free to get in so worth a quick look if you're passing.
Our guide spoke good English and took great interest in his job. The church is quite amazing. No photos allowed inside but that only cemented the experience for me.

There was a lot of history behind this church, and it is beautifully maintained. Our tour guide was young, but knowledgeable, and we enjoyed our time here. We went on a weekday during the day and ended up being there the same time as some local schools were doing tours, but our

This is a must! We visited the church with an English guide, a very knowledgeable social science student who guaranteed that we got all historical information. The site with the first column of the church in 1549 was impressive, also the visit to the roof top with bells!
Loved the tour, I was guided by a charming young lady that explained everything and I was very impressed. Very nice little tour.

The buildings are amazing, but it was the guide who made it special. A young woman named Helen who spoke excellent English explained the allegorical meanings of the paintings to me in a way that unlocked them for me -- I should add I've been to dozens of galleries all over the
We enjoyed the life and vivacity on the plaza outside of the church. The guide gave us an interesting accounting of the church's start and the early days of Catholocism in Bolivia

This church was founded in 1543 and has a lot of history. There two kinds of tours. The museum tour that takes you up to the bell tower and the church tour. I took the museum tour and was able to take some breath taking pics. Watch you step because the floor and steps are

We didn't have a plan on what to do after returning from Tiwanaku, so we decided to pop in and see the church. It was a beautiful place to visit! The tour guides (free of charge) were great and very knowledgeable, the architecture is beautiful and history of the place is great.

This is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever visited in Bolivia. It is a real historical treasure with a breathtaking architectural baroque style! The interior of the building looks expansive and the "retablos" are immensely rich and ornamented; not to mention the

We didn't go inside because it didn't look open. All the locals were sitting in front of the doors. It's a marvellous building to look at from outside anyway. The plaza is a great place to people watch. There is also a huge souvenir market behind and a huge food market in the
Wonderful Colonial Church in La Paz with a crypt beneath the basilica, have a museum in the colonial convent

The church was OK and the convent beside it, nicer. The guide who showed it was not really friendly, She just pointed out four times that 'if by accident you make one of the bells ring you should pay a big fine of 1000 BOV'.

A very building housing an imposing Cathedral of a neo classical style and not the common Baroc style found by most Catholic churches. The building with beautiful Greek style columns is plane but respectfull surrounded by wonderful stained glass made in Italy. The Cathedral was
the church is located in the central plaza. The inside is beautiful with large ceilings and beautiful stained glass
Right in down-town stands this church, the visit includes a tour to the SF monatesry/museum and the temple. My favorite part is to go up to the roof and see the city from there.

Very interesting church in the center of La Paz. I found that La Paz does not have that many exciting places to visit so this one is a must. Like most churches in southern America this one is richly decorated and the main altar is spectacular and do are the side altars.

This is a great place to visit and soak up the history. It's very crowded outside and can be loaded full of tourists. Be careful with your belongings. Read up on the history of this amazing church and the area as well is full of rich history - far away and recent history as

Glamorous, rich, splendid ... There are not too many places in La Paz that deserve a visit, this one definitely does. Decorated in the typical ostentatious manner this is a fantastic place to visit. The main altar is spectacular, much like the ones seen in churches in Peru.

I had been in La paz three times before i finally visited this magnificent gem in the heart of the city. the tour was cheap and well coordinated with excellent hosts that even spoke English. Very impressive service for such a cheap tour. The building and all the paintings are

This was an important church in the history of Bolivia and a visit is a very worthwhile experience. The cost is a paltry. 20 Bolivianos and includes a guided tour. We wandered about reading the English postings but joined a tour which took us to some places we could not access

The church in the middle of the city is Iglesia de San Francisco. Although the building itself is quite old and very impressive, I found the surrounding area to be much more interesting. Up the side street of the church is where you will find all the street vendors selling

Gloria was our tour guide. Great!! Tour was in Spanish, but I understand there is an English option. Very interesting tour with great works of art, then a visit to the top of the church for a birds eye view and a behind the scenes look at the running of the church. So much

Right from the intricate facade and into the church itself...one cannot but go back to the time when this was built, Spanish conquistadores laying what they must have seen a magnificent relic of christianity on South American soil, very rich in design and lavish in gold.

So much colour, a Bolivian flavour of the Catholic faith with strong Spanish roots. A mass started about 10 minutes after we arrived so we did curtail our visit somewhat, but we did enjoy the colourful interior & the facade even more.

The church is a great example of mestizo-baroque. Building and artworks from indigenous people and Spanish colonisers. The adjoining museum is well worth the visit. You can climb to have a great view of the elaborate roofs and tiles and to watch Paceños from above on their day
This was a beautiful place to visit and the museum was very interesting as well as the outside of this structure. Very crowded though so beware of your belongings.
You need to get the tour - they will take you places, like the belfry and the painting collection - you can't otherwise see.

This church has an amazing stone carved facade depicting natural themes. The interior has extravagantly carved altar pieces with abundant gold leaf. The cloisters house the museum which is well worth a visit as you get to see the choir, the dome roof and view the the interior
This is one of the old church here. The architecture is good.Quite crowed all the time.Worth the visit.

Many people hang out outside this church, people sitting on the footsteps of the church, either talking or eating or just resting. Quite an interesting site for me. I guess even the outside of the church bring some kind of comfort and rest. The inside of the church is amazing. I
Nice place to know the culture of la Paz and shout America but you have to watch out. It is no a safe place for tourist, take care you cameras, wallet and back pack
Very impressive Spanish style church that is a historic location in the city of La Paz. Sorry no pictures inside, but comeback at night for the free public shows and entertainment outside the church.

The museum basically consists of two rooms, one that explains the story of settlement and the other shows the old brewing equipment. The savior for our 20bs each was access to the roof of the church. Looking down into the church from the upper level was good and then using some
Really interesting Franciscan monastery and church-they have tours in English and Spanish. A lot of history, art and architecture to enjoy.
very nice and relaxing place to unwind and relax. Not a lot to do, would not make a special trip here again.

A historic church at the upper end of El Prado (main street in La Paz), in Plaza San Francisco, first built in 16th century, rebuilt in 18th century. You can go in church for free, and visit the museum for 20 Bolivianos (about £2), where they take you on a tour of the cloisters

You can visit the church itself without paying for a tour, and it is quite beautiful on its own. The architecture is very unique with many indigenous touches. However I would recommend that you pay for a tour at the museum next door. It cost us only 20 bolivianos and we were

With nothing to do in the city at the time I paid the entrance fee and didn't expect much. The church is so so beautiful and there's so many rooms to explore. Gorgeous courtyard outside with a garden and fountain. Once you get onto the top roof you have an amazing view of the
Beautiful church, and the included your was great too, really added to the experience, giving you a good history, not just of the church, but of the city too. Must see while in La Paz.

I'd say it's just another church. I was there when the pope visited and the area was quite animated. I prefered the plaza in front of the church to the church itself. This area of La Paz is quite touristical, but It's nice.

It's quite a beautiful church! I was lucky enough to be there during "Semana Santa". So there was plenty of activities outside the church. This also meant learning about the history regarding the church without taking the tour. I didn't take the tour this time I visited but I

San Francisco church is located at the end of Sagnagara, a main tourist shopping street. And is beautiful inside. Much more ornate than the main cathedral a few blocks away. Take time to come in to see the sanctuaries and main alter.

I typically get saddened by visiting churches of the conquering society, but in this case, this cathedral was fascinating to me. Pay attention to the foundation of the church, and the small ways that the Bolivian artisans worked in their own aesthetic and expression into the

Nice, but I didn't think it was that special or that it stood out from other churches. Still, the area around it is extremely lively - there are tour agencies, a market, accommodation, etc. that make it a good place to visit.

It is a very good place/ historic site to visit. It is right at the historic central part of La Paz. We love visiting historic sites and this one was very good and we really enjoyed visiting the whole of La Paz city

We have visited a lot if chr he's and whilst it does get a little repetitive, this one is pretty good. We got the free tour with our entry (but slipped a small tip to our guide) and we felt this was a nice way to learn about some if the history, and also be taken up the bell

Basílica de San Francisco and its adjoining museum are a gift to the traveler. One can climb to the belfry and enjoy a brilliant view of downtown La Paz. Mass service is also a very rewarding experience for catholic people.

Overall the church is nice and is located in a nice plaza, but it isn't spectacular. HOWEVER, the tour made it much more interesting. I thought it was a bit on the pricier side (bolivia standards) for a tour but it is guided (english or spanish) and lasts about 45 minutes. It is
Building is impressive, typical is churches in South America. Is visited by tourists and locals . At the entrance there is always something going on.
Great stop for a bit of history and chance to walk in the catacombs and see bones of monks in the past.
It is a nice old church in a cute area. The square is always full of people and the neighborhood around it is nice to explore.
Beautiful old church in a great part of the city. In all honestly we weren't the right people to appreciate a historic church, but it is impressive and worth a stop.
That's a beautiful church right in the middle of La Paz! Close to the most famous streets. It is beautiful also inside. During the day, the square in the front is always crowded.
amazing colonial old church in the center of la paz.our hotel was located very close to this church so we have had the chance to see it at different times of the day. quaint spot

This is an very impressing place to see, with art and artifacts all over its almost required to visit this place more than once. I had a great time for hours walking around this huge place which is open to public from the church floor to the spire with the bells. Especially one

Its free...its beautifull ....its....huge...images....it takes you back in time as soon as you get in....not sure if you can take pictures I guess you can....only at the museums you are not allowed to take pictures...
when I get there, a lot of policeman are getting ready for the carnival on the ground in front of the iglesia. it was crazy.
Beautiful facade and plaza outside The inside nothing spectacular and no fotos inside. Lots of souvenir shops in the side street but nothing notable.

This church is close to the witch market which is an area packed with attractions. The crurch itself is old and the interior is very well preserved. The outside is really intricate and just looking at the entrance is a treat.

The San Francisco church as it stands today is built on the site of an earlier one which was destroyed during a massive snowstorm that collapsed the building. The tour includes access to the bell tower. English speaking guides are available, though they are provided gratis
San Francisco is a central spot with lots of activities. Nice place to people watch. We had no problems but do get local advice on safety if you'll be there late in the evenings or at night.

I came to the church in the evening towards the end of a service. I only had about 20 minutes inside so we quickly made a round and ended up seeing most of the statues displayed. The day must have been quite sacred beause there was this little candle filled room that people

The church itself is big and is nice to see all the people around it, when I went for the first time there was a graduation going on and it was cool to see the locals there celebrating however the church itself is nothing extra special in terms of architecture or internal

The Church is quite impressive all though a lot smaller than I was expecting. Next door there is a museum with a wide collection of art that was pretty good. I actually preferred the Basilica further up the road.

Really like how the church makes a real effort to educate people on the history of la paz and the region as you tour through the church. They have signs in English, spanish, and French so you know exactly what you're looking at. Definitely go to the bell tower to look out over
Nice place to vista for an afternoon if you get stuck out in the rain. Some nice architecture, gives a brief history of La Paz and has some very nice art work.
It is an icon of La PAz, Life generates around it. The barroque architecture is very pretty and its shear size imposes, The altar is gorgeous. It is a must see.

We first went into the church and that was spectacular. I am non religious but this church is very impressive. It is very ornate with lots of gold leaf adorning the many saint platforms. The alter was beautiful and inspiring. Right next door is the museum. This is a MUST see. It

This church is on a busy street around the corner from the Witch's market. The streets are full of people and there are definitely people harassing foreigners for money. One followed my husband and I so closely and didn't take no for an answer that we eventually paid him to
Maybe the most beautiful structure in La Paz Nice location but be extremely careful as the place is notorious for thieves and pickpockets. Don't go alone but do go. Food in street good and reasonable
A stunning building in the centre of La Paz where you can sit for hours on the steps and watch the locals go about their business. It really was an amazing spot to people watch.
Very impresive church. It´s a nice place to hang (outside of course), lots of street artists do their shows at the square in front of the church...

We paid our 20 bobs each not knowing what to expect. The church is immense and OTT which had been our experience in most of Bolivia and Peru. You are able to climb up onto the roof via very narrow staircases. This affords views across the rooftops and to the courtyards below.

Watched from far = Amazing... Getting inside = Interesting!!. Personally i recomend to visit the church for a little tour, depending of the guide you will just leave the place amazed or with a lot of ( ??? ). I recomend to visit it at morning when you can go up to the bell tower

text.wiki:
La Paz (Spanish: "the peace") is a waterfall in central Costa Rica. In Spanish, it is known as Catarata de La Paz. It is 31 kilometres (19 mi) north of Alajuela, between Vara Blanca and Cinchona.
The waterfall is located immediately alongside the road from Alajuela that leads to the northern plains of Costa Rica. The River La Paz forms the waterfall after traversing 8 kilometres (5 mi) of volcanic terrain, and then continues through the rainforest of the eastern side of Poás Volcano. A short path leads behind the waterfall, where a small shrine had been located. Upstream from the waterfall is La Paz Waterfall Gardens, a hotel and park, where visitors can observe many different species of local wildlife.
The waterfall and surrounding area were severely damaged in the 6.1 magnitude earthquake of January 8, 2009. Landslides damaged the road that runs alongside the waterfall.


== References ==

sights.name: Cathedral Basilica of Our Lady of Peace

text.wiki:
The Cathedral Basilica of Our Lady of Peace  (Spanish: Catedral Basílica de Nuestra Señora de La Paz), also called La Paz Cathedral, is a cathedral and minor basilica is located in Murillo Square in the city of La Paz in Bolivia. It was built in 1835 with a neoclassical architecture with Baroque elements. It has an interior consisting of five naves  with different layers.
The first cathedral of La Paz was completed in 1692 after 70 years of construction; the first building was made of stone, lime and brick. In 1831 it was decided to demolish it due to the collapse of his presbytery and several cracks that threatened its collapse. The construction of the current cathedral began on March 24, 1835; it was inaugurated in 1925, marking the first centenary of the founding of the Republic of Bolivia. Although it opened that year, its interior ornamentation still continued until 1932.
In 1989, its two lateral towers were opened, this event coinciding with the visit of Pope John Paul II.


== See also ==
Roman Catholicism in Bolivia
Cathedral Basilica of Our Lady of Peace


== References ==
text.quote: Large cathedral featuring a soaring dome, neoclassical ornamentation & an Italian marble altar.
trip: Enjoyed our visit to the cathedral which is just a few blocks from the malecon in the center of town. Beautiful cathedral. They were redoing all the outside gardens and walkways so it will even be more beautiful in a few weeks. Must visit when in town.

We were told the 2 columns of this cathedral were built at 2 different times. The left side was built in the the 1918 and the right side in 1928. Overall a nice place to visit so some relaxing down time

A nice little church with a plain interior. Like the wooden roof with the circular cupola in the middle. They are presently working on the square in front and the government offices so it is not very peaceful, but will be beautiful when they are finished.

Not extraordinary, humble place, where people go in crowds. We visited the Cathedral on Sunday, just before the noon. It was more than full, the service was going on - all impressive and nice to see and hear. Neatly decorated interior.

During our brief visit to La Paz as part of a day-long tour from Cabo san Lucas, our Esperanza's Tours La Paz Encounter tour stopped here. We were able to enjoy the sanctuary and take photographs of the interior and exterior. This is a well-kept building. The skylight in the

One of the top places to visit in La Paz and easy to find. If your lucky a tour group will be there and you can listen in on the history which adds to the Cathedral. Important part of the community and worth visiting if you are here.

Not a grand or imposing cathedral, but it felt very "sincere." There's a bit of interpretive history nearby, and it's on the way to a walk to the local English-language bookstore. Worth a stop, especially for the faithful, to enjoy the religious experience and a sense of the
We went here on a tour. Great history and it seems well cared for. This was built by the Jesuits when they came into Mexico and we were given history of what they did while there.

We have seen many cathedrals in Mexico and this is not the best, nor the worst but it is a beautiful church, both inside and out. In fact, the outside is very simple but there is a simple elegance inside with its yellow domed arches and white trim. There are two plaques

It sits at one side of the town square and is very basic and simple but was worth a 5 minute photo opp and peak inside. Nothing like other Cathedrals you may be thinking of or what you see in Europe but nice local culture.
It's not overly fancy, but it is sincere and soulful - very locally spiritual. Worth a few minutes to get there and a quiet, meditative visit.

This cathedral is small and fairly plain compared to other cathedrals I have seen. It is lovely, none the less. The statues and decor in Catholic churches are always interesting to me. The square in front of the church is nice as well. There are benches and it serves as a
Not the most ornate or impressive church in Mexico by far ... but OK for a quick look. There are more interesting things to see in La Paz.
this is normal church, not flamboyant. If your looking for a cathedral this is not it But it is a nice spot to learn about the culture

Beautiful to see. It is a must if you are in LaPaz. So much history. I have to admit. I have been to Europe and have seen some amazing churches.This is probably a sanctuary for the people of Mexico as a community.
Pretty stained glass windows, small and intimate. There was a lovely tiny chapel with individuals praying. The altar had flowers very pretty well maintained. Close to shopping and city building
the cathedral was beautiful. did not have enough time in there to see all the statues. we were rushed by our tour guide. excursion offered per princess cruise
This is a beautiful old cathedral and should be of interest to folks that like historical buildings. It is magnificent

The cathedral is beautiful. We stopped in to take some photos and came across a christening. In fact, they were christening a number of people of all ages, from baby to senior citizens. It was quite moving and interesting to watch.
Despite the exterior's larger scale the interior of the cathedral is small and intimate. Really lovely.
It's worth a look if you are passing by, but it's nothing special so don't go out of your way to see it.

I have visited Catholic cathedrals in many different countries and this one has to be the most unadorned cathedral I have ever seen. This is not a criticism, just a fact. A short visit of 10 minutes will be enough.

I'm fascinated by the devotion to churches and cathedrals in Mexico. Their devotion to living a blessed life is beautiful. The detail in all Mexican churches shows their love so I can never say enough good about visiting any Cathedral in Mexico

Beautiful old cathedral, not big if compared to older European cathedrals, but it must have been enormous for the population that the peninsula used to have. Great place to visit, bells still ring on the hour, and it's only 2 blocks from the beach and touristy area. Bonus, to
The Cathedral in Central La Paz is a step back to the Old Mexico. Church bells ringing and the structure do reminiscent of hundreds of years ago. A must see for everyone
Thank you for the opportunity pray to you, to sing to you in Spanish. Thank you for a safe and enjoyable time with friends.
Very nice old cathedral...cornerstone laid in 1861. Went thru in the morning and happened to come by in the afternoon while a wedding was taking place...charming!

Not impress of the upkeep and not so historical there's nothing to be surprise like a wow factor.... Very simple less parking and less touristy not unlike the cathedrals in Austria, or European countries.

this is a fine old church... and a good place to meditate and get away from the pounding sounds of the city.... as i fallen catholic i found some peace and quiet without too much guilt just sitting in the church ...
A beautiful cathedral in the heart of La Paz. We had a wonderful walk through, and the plaza was a great place to soak in the city.
This church was built in the 1800's and has never been remodeled and it looks as if it was just done. Great altar and for Christmas had the best manger scene I have ever seen
This is a nice very small church in the middle of town. You can walk around or try some of the small coffee shops or restaurants around it.

Simple, pretty Church. But one can feel the grandeur mixed with the difficulty of the architecture for the materials available at the time. (i.e. crystal chandeliers, curved wooden ceiling). I would have loved to attend a service, but the decorations were fabulous. And the fact
Nice, traditional Spainish architecture made all festive for the Christmas Holidays. Friendly, enjoyable atmosphere and open to wander in and have a look.
no reason not to stop by and poke your head in, but nothing too exciting. The cathedral under construction is also worth a peak, even in its completely unfinished state, just because its so big.
Mexico has many very grand cathedrals. This is not one of them. To get the true flavor of this place, it's necessary to attend a service here and experience the devotion of the parishioners.

I agree with Friar 4 our Cathedral is not impressive by any means whatsoever compared to other Cathedrals in the world. I think the one in Guadalajara is much more impressive. However... take in account WHERE we are, and WHEN it was built, and then you could say it is

One needs to walk up a street from where the tour buses let you off, but it's worth the walk. The cathedral is very quaint, and we were able to watch a service take place. The architecture is very pretty, and it's amazing to see how they much they built with just stone. A major
Worth a visit. Impressive stone cathedral in this dusty humble Baja Town. Faces the town square. Good energy inside.

This Cathedral was built in the 1800's. It's nice and in use by the locals. If you have seen many Cathedrals, you won't be wowed. It is across from Plaza de la Constitucion, which is also OK. I wouldn't rank these sites as major draws for La Paz.
The La Paz cathedral is worth a visit. Like most Spanish colonial churches in Mexico the architecture alone is worth the visit. Check it out!
A beautiful old Cathedral. Just sit in a pew and feel the serenity wash over you. An absolute must stop by for anyone with a real interest in the history of La Paz.
Not a fabulous building but nice. Worth a look. Not difficult to park for awhile. Good photo op for recording visit to la Paz.
Worth a pop in to see the chandeliers and the art. The virgin de Guadalupe was very nice. Worth a ten minute stop!

La Paz Cathedral is a small gem in downtown La Paz. Beautifully decorated and serene, it's a restful place and well worth a visit. Peaceful atmosphere and a long history, nicely explained in the entry signs in both Spanish and English.

The building is not fancy but it is amazing; I was able to find something new in the structure every time I looked at it. The inside is great--a house of worship, plain and simple, but with heartfelt stained glass and altars that evoked deep feelings in us. The church is a

What a beautiful cathedral, one of the best on the baja peninsula....everytime we visit LaPaz we go here and stand in awe. A must see while visiting LaPaz , and cathedral adjoins the old zocalo and band stand. Historic La Paz at it's

There are plaques at the entrance one in Spanish, other in English giving information and dates about the development of this lovely cathedral. It's a quick visit, however I did see several tourists enjoying the silence and beauty of the interior.
I attended a wedding in this beautiful cathedral. it was majestic and very nicely maintained. It's truly a place to see while visiting LaPaz. The Cathedral will not disappoint you and your friends.

The Cathedral is a simple church, very well maintained, clean and peaceful. The square in front of the Cathedral is where the local people goes to flirt and talk to the others as it is common in small villages.

Stunning architecture and intriguing history... this is a must see in my opinion. This is truly a jewel within the city and a beautiful photo op. If you are lucky enough to attend an event here it is well worth the time!
This is a small but beautiful cathedral, impressed with the upkeep and decoration. Parking was easy and it was not hard to find.
The cathedral is a must when visiting La Paz. I didn't realize it was such a historical site until I read the inscripture on the outside. Located in a nice area to walk around in and explore.
This cathedral is incredible. The beauty of it takes you by surprise and it is very easy to walk to and the square is very well kept.

Fantastic and beautiful architecture. Visit this fabulous cathedral, enjoy its superb architecture and once you´re done, accross the street is town square and its quaint kiosk. Enjoy it along an ice cream and playing mexican bingo "loteria"
Nice Cathedral and a historical site. Easy to get to and great pictures to be taken. People are very friendly and helpful .

This cathedral is the original, and in the center of the waterfront shopping area. It's open to the public, yet is still in use. Walk through and see the architecture, icons, and other decorations. The cathedral and the grounds are a true gathering place for the locals.

I love this land mark so historical. This hole area grab a coffee from Cafe Gourmet say hi to the americans that hang out outside on almost a daily basis, talk to them tell them Donna Sent you and when you hear the churchbells check it out. I sit at the back due to my so-so
neat area to walk around. Not the most amazing Cathedral I've even seen but it was nice. It was pretty but not all that much to do in the area, only takes a few minutes to see the Cathedral
Serenity and peace surround The Cathedral and the surrounding square.
It is very ornate inside, beautiful! Very nice area of town with the park across the street. We love La Paz!
I liked the opportunity to shoot some very nice photos, using interior light that sprayed through the stained glass.
If you have visited Mexico this will not impress you, it is however interesting
What a lovely church. I loved the brick, and the architecture, and the gardens surrounding it.
