text.wiki:
Playa Balandra is a beach located on the Baja California Sur peninsula of Mexico in La Paz.  It is located on the Eastern side of the peninsula, but faces west, as the southern tip comes up.


== External links ==
 Media related to Playa Balandra at Wikimedia Commons
text.quote: Scenic, white-sand shoreline with clear, sheltered waters & a backdrop of low-lying hills.
trip: Don't come to Baja or La Paz during the pandemic. Is a ghost town and the customer services are the worst. All. I mean all the beaches are closed. Near and far. I understand the social distances criteria. However, how I'm going to transmit the virus at an empty beach is beyond
exquisite location, if mars had water in the past it would probably looked like this, in fact this scenery looks out of this world!

Easy to get from La Paz to Balandra Beach, half an hour by car, taxi or bus. beach where you can walk for up to 800 meters with the water at your waist and 100% transparent full of colorful and shaped fish. Between 2 hills and a cliff is this wonderful beach where the famous

A bus from the local bus terminal will bring you here in 45 minutes. It feels like you're in another world with the gorgeous scenery. Bring food and drinks. There are only a few small carts with snacks and water.

this atraction should be the number 1 atraction in la paz, nothing can beat it, it is such a calm and beautiful beach with an otherworldly sense of tranquility, if you are from another country you will definitely love this experience

Go early in the morning to avoid crowds. We were the only ones there at 8 am in a weekday. If you are fit, walk up to hill above the bay to take in the vista. The view is breathtaking. I wish we’d had time to rent a kayak.

I cannot think of a beach lagoon with water that looks so sparkling and clear. Our day trip out and back by bus was the highlight of our five days in La Paz. Go during the week to avoid crowds and snag yourself a free palapa. Absolute heaven!
Nice beach with a few amenities. We rented a kayak and spent a couple hours paddling around. Nice place to spend some time. Go early because the parking lot fills up.

It wasn't so much the crowds, but the food concession and beach peddlers that disappointed me. I went there expecting a pristine UNESCO protected beach, with no food or bathroom facilities. We arrived complete with a cooler, towels and our own bathroom supplies. It was wall

Beautiful beach outside of la Paz. Head north up highway 11 and you’ll see the signs for balandra. It’s really easy to find. Follow signs towards pichilinque then to balandra. After balandra I’d you’re hungry cruise about 3-5 miles towards tecelote for food, drinks, another
Fun to enjoy the water and sun! Such a great beach for kids-- so shallow for so long. Just ok for snorkeling.

There is nothing in comparison to Balandra’s natural beauty, blue calm waters and the shallow nature of this body of water. However, over advertising it has made it crowded with visitors, bus loads full. The peaceful nature has been destroyed, but the beauty remains.

We have been all over Mexico and this is the most beautiful white sandy beach we have seen. It is missing services and facilities which is a real problem. Definitely worth a visit but Tecolote Beach less than a mile away is also very nice and has lots of facilities and plenty

Balandra Beach is so breathtaking--you won't be disappointed! It does get crowded on weekends (we were there on Constitution Day, so like a weekend), but it emptied after 4 pm. Kayaks are available to rent, so that is very convenient.

This was a cool beach , and I arrived via boat from La Paz. It’s cool to be able to walk in very shallow water for many miles with no waves BUT I will advise that my particular visit did not look as pretty as the pictures. There’s lots of pelicans. We did paddle boarding. I was

This is a gorgeous beach you can easily spend the day at. There are fresh fruit stands, a refreshment stand and a some people selling bread/empanadas. It’s worth a walk up on the hill for a really nice view! The water is quite shallow so you can walk around easily

This was my first time visiting this place and this nice and peaceful beach. The water is so clear, you can walk into the beach and water will just go above your ankles, and then by your knees. Nice place to go!

We went to Balandra Beach at the suggestion of the owners of our hotel. We were in Todos Santos, so the route was to La Paz, then past it. Worth it! Parking was a minor issue, but we were there on a week day and I imagine it would be a lot worse on the weekend. But such a
playa Balandre is one of the most famous and amazing place on the earth, we were there early in the morning to enjoy the beach and the enviroment
Wonderful fine, white sand beach. Hidden away a little and not overly busy. When the tide is down you can go out pretty far from the beach on some sand bars.
A beautiful shallow water beach, emerald green water. The road isn’t the best but worth the trip. We drove from Cabo to La Paz 2 1/2 hr drive
Beautiful place,. Two couples travelling together. The men hiked to the top and took pictures of the amazing views. Ordered lunch on the beach from Ceasar. Loved the 2hole experience

The only reason I am giving this a low rating is so you may be warned that there are stingrays actually several smaller ones that blend in with the sand and they have the tiniest warning signs at the entrance of the beach so that they don’t scare tourists off but don’t get me

We drove 2 hours each way to get to Balandra Beach and although it was a beautiful beach, I don't think I'd take my whole day to do this trip again. But if you are close, definitely visit. Make sure that when you park, you realize that around the corner of the rocks, is a

This was a very interesting beach! The water was very shallow, even at high tide, so you could walk around the point to get to the next point with the mushroom rock. However, we chose to hike over the ridge - not difficult, and on to the next ridge. We were rewarded with

Take your own food and drink and enjoy this lovely beach about about 5 miles from La Paz. It seems further. Sadly you need a vehicle to get there. There are a few vendors and interesting group of beachgoers. Nice sand, pretty water pretty clean considering that it's

Was a total let down. If this is a must see in LA Paz, don't waste your time the pictures did not look like the real thing. My wife had to use the bathroom, it was discussing, there was human feces all over the seat. 2 lady's where charging for toilet paper ane hand sanitizer

When you go to Playa Balandra, be ready (at least on weekends) for a crush of people and challenging parking. The beach is crowded. Tha said, the beaches are also splendidly beautiful and are of soft sand. There are some steep, but not-too-difficult hikes up the headland that
What a beautiful place and thankfully fully protected from the development sharks to keep it a national treasure for Mexicans and travellers alike. Absolutely beautiful.
beautiful ! worth the visit, best not on weekends as it can get a bit crowded stunning water color , easy to get to

This beach is definitely out of the way, but it felt like discovering a lovely hidden secret. It felt like an authentic, non touristy Mexico experience. White sand, dramatic bluffs, desert landscapes, the clear shallow blue water of the bay on the Sea of Cortez, families
Balandra Beach is a must visit for all. Clear shallow water suitable for all. Clean sandy beach a great place to spend a few hours or the entire day.

I went to Balendra on a whale shark/ sea lion combo tour with La Paz VIP tours. The beach itself is a wonder, where desert meets sea. Its right around the corner from San Rafaelino, a sea lion colony of about 70 animals that VIP uses as an alternative in January when the seas
Amazing views. Go early to find park g and a spot on the beach as it gets busy as the morning goes on. You can wade in the shallow waters for ever!

This is the prettiest beach in Mexico I’ve been too. The only other part of Mexico that might have beaches that would beat this beach is in the Riviera Maya (where places like Cancun and Cozumel are located).

One of the loveliest beaches I’ve seen! Clean sand and Shallow clear, warm water for half a mile out. Fab vistas. You can rent umbrellas or a palapa and picnic all day. Calm waters- great kayaking or even swimming if you get to deeper water. Fruit/juice/ snack shacks and

Visited this beach twice whilst in La Paz. Such a lovely place to sit around for a few hours - take your own food/ drink as there’s not really much choice there. We hired a kayak and paddled over to one of the beaches on the other side of the bay. Lovely to have our own private
This is one of our favorite beaches in the La Paz area. The addition of washrooms at the beach is a huge improvement.

One if the most beautiful beaches I've been to in Mexico. Lots of locals go to Balandra so there are families, couples and friends. Make sure and walk around to the right of the beach. There is more beach and not as crowded. You can walk in the water because its shallow for a

One giant sandbar that allows you to walk to beaches where you will be the only one. Warm water that is perfect for wading and sitting and relaxing. You can venture out to where you can snorkel. Little to no waves so this beach is perfect for small children or elderly. No

Beautiful beach! At the time of writing (January 2020) you can take the bus from the tourist bus station at the Malecon for about 150 pesos return. The bus leaves the Malecon every hour on the hour and departs the beach every hour on the :20. Beautiful spot and well worth a day.
Such a beautiful beach to play on and have a lunch on. Sand was absolutely amazing. At low tide you can walk across the bay.

this is the most incredible beach I´ve ever seen in my life, at this place you can´t miss the mushroom, dont go on weekends it is crowded, you can go on the rest of the week and early in the morning, you will have the beach just for you, the best season is at the begining of

Took a day trip from La Paz and came across Ballandra Beach. The gentle hike to the view spot was gorgeous. The beach is so pretty- although it was busy with a cruise ship group. Wear water shoes though!

Even after reading about how beautiful it was, it was better than I expected. We took a 20 min Uber ride from La Paz that cost less than 200 MXN and arrived just before noon. It was a Saturday and it was fairly busy but still plenty of space to relax. There was hardly any cell

The beach is picturesque and idealistic. Clear waters and cool breezes. However the sand hides a lot of sand fleas. Don’t lay your towels on the sand better to use the beach umbrella and seats you can rent. If you do get bites, please get some anti itch cream. Better to get it
We are and wandered the shallows with our babe in arms. Warm water and very safe. Worth the short, pleasant drive out of town. Check the tide chart before you go.

I couldn’t wait to go to this place because of all the rave reviews. It was beautiful, but certainly not jaw dropping like some beaches in the Caribbean. I guess if we didn’t have to drive 2 hours from Cabo to get there it would be worth the trip. I wouldn’t bother unless you
This is a nice place not windy like Tecolote . Water cold, you can buy a coconut , there are kayaking there is a
The travel was long from Cabo San Lucas but all worth it. Be careful with cows crossing as we almost got into an accident. They have signs and believe those signs.
the unfortunate downside of being beautiful and promoted = huge hordes of people. Balandra is hardly enjoyable these days. And soon they will be building condos nearby.

This is a quiet and secluded beach. We felt relaxed and peaceful here. This was part of a tour we took and we only stayed for about an hour and ate lunch. But the water is calm and clear. We thoroughly enjoyed this little piece of heaven.

14/12 We three British middle aged guys were touring in BC in the first half of December. We had heard about this famous beach and along with a Spanish friend took an Uber from our Apartment (200) all the way, taking about half an hour (some road renovations slowed us down for

Shallow waters make this pretty bay safe and family friendly. Its a very large bay with multiple sandbanks so you can wade out for 100m at waist height, whilst watching feeding pelicans and other seabirds and gazing at fish and crabs in clear water. The famous mushroom rock

Playa Balandra is a small bay 2 minutes from Playa el Tecolote. The beach is quite busy with tourists. Beautiful turquoise waters. It is very shallow so you can walk around in water up to you knees. Not many swimming opportunities though.
Really awesome spot. Took an Uber up there for a few hours. The bay is really pretty, and we brought our snorkel masks and saw lots of fish on the far end of the bay. Warm waters

The largest sandy lagoon I have ever seen, this beach remains in my memory as a paradisical spot. It's important to go at high tide - even then the water is very shallow and you can walk almost across the bay! You can bring a picnic but there are some refreshments available on

Balandra Beach in La Paz is an awesome beach and nobody should miss a stop here when they are visiting the Los Cabos area. Even the drive to the beach is very scenic and enjoyable. Parking space is limited at the beach, so go early. Once at the beach, one should not miss the

Beautiful beach. Lots of locals. Rent a car and drive yourself. There is a snack van and plenty of parking. The drive is easy and uneventful.

Turquoise waters, swimmable beach, clear and clean. I’ve got no negative remarks. Absolutely beautiful!!

another beautiful beach from baja but this is a very special one, there no waves just you and the desert

Incredible view, sand and water! Go early and try to stay to the far left. And climb the mountain to see on the the best views you can find!

Great time, reasonable prices. Loved our stay. Nice that it was a short trip by bot to the whale shark feeding area.

Spent an afternoon. Very enjoyable with food available in the parking lot and walk to see mushroom rock. Very unique.
This is one of the nicest beaches, I totally recomend it. It a little far to get to the Pic. But it is totally worth it.

Went to beautiful Balandra Beach with MeXplore Tours. Great time. Started the tour with the whale sharks and had lunch on the beach. A place to go see.

shallow, clear water, soft sand. great place for kids to play and swim. we had a picnic and the kids found lots of fish skeletons and cool things!

The beach was picture perfect and super warm. Even with a few people there it did not seem crowded. A great way to spend two or three hours.

Wow ! So pretty here just go see it! Everywhere you look here it’s gorgeous! We loved it so much we went back the next day!
Beautiful here, but you need to be prepared for no bathroom and no bar or restaurant. The water is calm as a bathtub. Lots of interesting birds to see.

This place is the busiest beach we visited while in Baja Sur. The main beach was a little crowded, so we waded around the rock point to the second beach and had a great time sunning and swimming. The only good snorkeling we found was on the rocks near the mushroom rock. There's
This places is so beautiful, it’s my favorite beach of baja! I love spending all day at this beach and the color of the water is beautiful

We were lucky enough to make it out here several times during out visit to La Paz and is always worth the trip! It is a beautiful spot!
Extremely beautifully clear water . Great place to spend the day.. We packed a cooler and spent the entire day

The public beach has parking and porta potties, incredible views, warm shallow waters, white sand and was very clean when we were there on a Saturday. Plenty of space to spread out too. Other beaches in the area can be reached only by boat and are also spectacular. Take a photo

This beach is pretty amazing totally chill, guys selling hats and food kids playing nobody acting stupid the clearest calmest water I've ever seen white sand, slight drive to get to but no big deal. I'd give it 5 stars but at the end of the day it still just a beach.

This is a must while visiting La Paz. The bays are full of colors and life. The parking lot leads to one of the bays that most of the people go to. I would recommend going over the small hill and go to the other bay. Bring snorkel gear, umbrella and environmentally safe

Great beach for kids, a few vendors with umbrellas, etc. Make sure your trip does not coincide with a ferry departure - took us more than 1hr from La Paz due to ferry traffic. Our toddler loved the water, but I have never seen so many wasps in one place.

Driving from las Cabos to la Paz is scenic and interesting drive on mostly well-paved divided Hwy. The malecon walk and drive thru the centro area are the main attractions of the town. The Balandra Beach is not worth spending time to drive. Contrary to our expectation that the
One of the most beautiful beaches I have ever seen. A true gem with clear and calm waters and beautiful hikes

The beach is beautiful but full of algae. There is a lot of people and a lot of noise and music. The parking is just next to the beach which is very ugly. You can climb the mountains and walk all the beach across.

The water is crystal clear and you can walk around the cove as the water is chest high at the deepest point. There are 2 coves to explore. Kayak & SUP boards available to rent. I would bring a float, sunscreen, a small cooler, and sun umbrella. Uber is available and very

If you are visiting, you can rent an umbrella, chair and get food and drink at the beach. Of course, you can always bring your own. Not much for snorkeling, but it is a relaxing spot to soak up some sand. There is a public bathroom there as well.
As part of our tour with VIP tours, Captain Eddy and guide Katrin prepared a great lunch on the beach. We'l come back on our own as it is an easy drive from La Paz.

We decided to head to Balandra after visiting La Ventana and the area (actually we did a big loop from El Triunfo, up to La Ventana and then to Balandra Beach which was a nice way to spend a day). There were still a lot of people at the beach and in the water which looked as if

This is a wonderful beach about 20 mins drive from La Paz. We got there around 10 am and found it to be quite and easy to park. Contrary to other reviews the is a refreshment truck selling drinks and snacks, and also toilet facilities ( just think of a massive litter box for

As we were driving....we came across this beautiful beach! When we arrived, there was only 2 other couples there. Later in the day it got busier. We came in the mid morning and then stopped to have lunch down the road to another great find!

We (2 adults and an 11 year old) spent an afternoon at this beach. This one is in my opinion the best 'family' beach. Warm clean waters, shallow beach, and white soft sand. What more can you ask for! And if that isn't enough at low tide you can walk along the shoreline to the

Definitely preferred this beach hands down over Tecolote beach! Palapas are free to the public. Get there early and stay all day! Bring lunch, water, snacks in a cooler because no restaurants around. Beach is super clean, water is pristine and you can walk out prettty far and

A must while in La paz or cabo. A 2:30 hour drive from cabo this is truly one of the most beautiful beaches on earth. Peaceful and clean. Highly recommend to BOB since there is no restaurants or stores.

I really liked Balandra Beach its really nice and the water is very warm. Please help keep this area clean when going. Note: this location does not have restrooms or changing area, since its a protected area by the government.
Amazing bay! The water is crystal clear, cactuses all around the hills. If you rent a car you should take a visit even if your hotel is in San Jose Del Cabo like ours.
A must when visiting La Paz or Los Cabos. Nice, beautiful, clean. A real jewel. Take care of our planet and be conscious. Keep it clean. Nice people and attention. A must...

This is a beautifull little cove just north of La Paz if you want to kick back on the beach and relax, It could do with a little resturant or a bar or even a shack that served food and drinks but worth a visit if you're in the vicinity.

This was our favorite beach. Very nice and peaceful. The level of the water would barely go over your knees. Depending on the day, there could be almost no waves which makes it perfect for kids or people who are afraid of waves. Important to know: there are a few free Palapas,

The perfect beach at the perfect location. We went during the week and it was not packed. I can see on the weekends the place being full but we were lucky to get one of the palapas and enjoyed a lovely day in this piece of paradise. A must when visiting La Paz
Although it’s a little bit overrated, as you need to walk more than 100 meters to get the water pass your knees, is a nice and safe beach to go with little ones.

This quiet beach is absolutely gorgeous! Shallow turquoise water await to refresh and soothe you. The contrast against the white sand and arid backdrop is stunning! Not much in terms of activity... which is part of the charm! You CAN rent some kayaks and there is one

We made the trip from Cabo to Balandra with much anticipation. Positives? Great coconut stand and soft sand. If you have kids it allows for wading without too much worry. Negatives? We found the beach a little smelly with dark weeds on parts of the sandy shoreline which was not

Beautiful place with a nice blue water, but when we went, the tour man told us it was the first time in his life that the place was crazy crowded, so we didn’t enjoy the please . It was impossible to get to the “ mushroom spot” because it was too many people , but when we went

Balandra was spectacular, its the first I strolled in the beach..water was so clean & clear and you can walk from the shore and across walking..although the the end acroos is a deep cavity that you can’t see the bottom so be careful...water was warm & perfect for non
Easy to find, good parking area, very clean, shallow water, great to take children and pet. No restaurants in the area, BYO food and drinks or go to Tecolote next to it for lunch

I’ve been to most of the best beaches all over the world and Balandra Beach is right there in the top.It is the most beautiful place,many different coves that all face different directions.Each one more amazing than the last.Kayaks are available for rent and you can paddle

Balandra is amazing! You can swim in clean waters, I recommend you to use snorkel equipment. If you arrive on morning you have the beach only for you. You can also do Kyak and aquatic sports in this beach. Greetings from Portugal

Balandra Beach is a beautiful retreat about 2 hours from Los Cabos. It is worth a day trip! The water is crystal clear and very warm. It is a lagoon so there are no waves or rip currents. There are some local vendors with fresh fruit, beverages, shaved ice and souvenirs.

Great place for kids, very shallow waters. A must see attraction if you can't surf, but want to relax in the water. You can wade hundreds of meters out to sea, and a few vendors had delicious mangos on a stick.
White sands, turquoise water, good palapa and also a place to rent umbrellas and buy something Everything you need to enjoy a great beach
Not to miss when visiting La Paz. 30 minutes by car. Sandy White beaches, great for snorkeling. Suggestion take an umbrella and chairs and cooler with food and drinks. Don't miss this place

The beach is gorgeous, but if you happen to be there during the weekend be ready to share the beauty with many many other people. We got there a little before noon and the beach was already pretty packed, but more people kept arriving steadily all afternoon. If you're not

Certainly not what it used to be, does not live up to the hype anymore. Still a very nice beach in the early hours before it becomes super crowded. Perfect spot for kids, safe shallow crystal clear waters. No restroom or other services. Get there early and grab a free family

My cousins and I came to Playa Balandra from Cabo San Lucas. Unfortunately, we came on a Sunday and it was packed, no area to put our stuff, visitors with loud DJ speakers. We decided to go to Playa Tecolote.

we went here as part of the boat tour with the cortez club so they dropped us here while the divers went out. it's a pretty little spot with crystal clear water and a nice beach. they have a mushroom rock to look at and you can snorkel there as well. it was empty in the
Not as cool as it used to be. Bit dirty nowadays. Super crowded. I rather visit other beaches. Small parking lot.

I read all the wonderful reviews and was so hyped to take my teen son there. Got there on a Tuesday about 1PM and was so disappointed. Car lot was full and people were parked along both sides of a one lane unpaved road leading up to entrance so our van guide couldn't drive in. I
Loved this beach, it was very busy when we went. Bring lots of water and snacks, and an umbrella for shade.

We have spent several days at Balandra so far this trip, and it is our favorite hangout in La Paz. Heartily recommended. We have been riding the public bus from the terminal on the Malecon (just across from the two story waterfront pavillion) near the whale museum. Ecobaja

Came here on the city bus from la Paz. Earliest bus is at 10am 100 pesos rt then it runs every 2 hours coming back. Beautiful and quiet when you get there early. There are palapas on the beach for shade. If they are all taken people don’t mind sharing. You spend most of your

This is an extraordinary place unprecedented in my experience. The whole huge bay it set in the midst of desert hills about a half-hour drive from La Paz. There are no bathrooms or restaurants at the beach, just a few food trucks. Its a locals family beach. The whole bay is

Highlight of our trip to la Paz. Water has great visibility and super shallow. We could see the little fish swim around and could walk half way across the beach with the water until our waist. Most beautiful sunset of our lives!

This location is well worth a stop. It is a part of the natural preserve. It is very pretty and a clean area. On the day we visited, it was a bit cloudy and we got a break from the heat of the sun. This area has no staff members to help with questions and answers. There were

Beautiful beach with pure white sand and shallow water. There are no facilities so pack a cooler, sunscreen, beach umbrella and snacks for a fun day. Bring your favorite floats to soak up the sun or snorkel. Approximately 3 hour drive each way from Cabo San Lucas.
This one is clean and looks like a pool. My favorite from the area. Make sure you were swimming shoes.
All a good experience. The favorite locals beach they say. We were given chairs to sit on the beach. Good place for children.

Our friends and we like to leave our "stuff" on the beach and walk out a little into the water and plant our umbrellas and chairs. It's fun sitting in the water. If you go out further, you need to shuffle your feet so the little rays know you're coming their way so they have
I can honestly say this is the nicest beach I have ever been to, the sand is so nice and soft, the water is so clear It feels like a big pool, awesome place to visit!
if you're in la paz you have to explore this beach. bring some ceviche, water, beer and you're good to go :)
A great place to relax, but a bit crowded sometimes. You can easily walk across the bay if the crowds get too much. Not much snorkeling. Great views from the hill overlooking the bay.

Wow! I thought it was so beautiful here. Shallow, warm water that is perfectly still. I could have swam around all day. It was part of a tour so only had an hour. If you like swimming and the beach it is a must go while in La Paz.

Balandra is an amazing beach young children and adults love this beach. About 2 miles of walking inside the warm water which never reach above our shoulders. Crystal clear water. Just beautiful. We adore this place.

About 2 hours drive from Cabo. It’s a hidden gem. We have visited so many beaches around the world, and this one is on the top of the list. Nature at its best. You can rent an umbrella and relax. Make sure you stop by la Paz for seafood on your way back
Nice outing with a visiting amigo. When you go bring your own umbrella or get there early to score one of the many pomfon shaded areas on the shore

This beach is absolutely gorgeous. Traveling with small children we have to be mindful of the waves and the water was absolutely perfect for our toddler here. It was something out of a postcard! We tried going the first time but didn’t arrive until 11 and the palapa were all

We thoroughly enjoyed this beach, only a short trip from La Paz. Kayaked in the mangroves and walked through the crystal clear, warm waters. You don’t need a mask and snorkle to see an array of sea life. Next time we’d take a cooler with cerveza and maybe a few snacks since

We rented a car from Cabo to head this way, it was well worth the drive. The beaches are white, warm waters and crystal clear you can walk for miles in waste high water. Bring you own food and drinks as the cart is very expensive since it’s unpopulated. You can rent paddles

This beautiful beach was full of surprises. Maybe because I didn't do my homework, went on a whim and had no idea what to expect. Many wouldn't drive 2 hours out of Cabo San Lucas (the tourist area) and come to a beach they only heard from a local "was beautiful and you can wade
If you visit La Paz, Balandra beach is a must. Its a very safe beach, and you can walk inside the sea more that 100 yards. The scenario is amazing combining the dessert and the sea.

Go as early as possible! One time we went by car around sunrise and it was so magical. There was no one there, climbed up the little mountain for a perfect view and enjoyed it so much. If you go early you are sure you have a beach umbrella to project yourself against the sun.

Balandra is one of my favorite beaches to visit in La Paz BCS. It is located about 25min drive from La Paz. The beach offers turquoise blue clear waters that are amazing to walk and swim into. You can walk hundreds of feet into the ocean and will not sink in, 3-4ft deep. It's a

Unadulterated beauty is necessary in this world. Why, one might ask, is it necessary? I say it is because of the potential for a sort of epiphany one might experience in the magnificence of the natural world that is not possible through any other medium of human expression;
Came here and it was amazing, crystal clear waters and light blue colors. there was just some garbage around which was disappointing.

The most gorgeous beach ever!!! You can walk and walk and the cristal clear water doesn't go higher than you're waist. It has beautiful white sandy beaches and it's an adventure to get to the famous rock!! Worth the climb through the rocks!!! One of my favorite places to go!!!
2nd time in this beach and it is just very amazing. Last time there was no people, but this time, although it was crowded, we enjoyed very much. Worth going there even if you are in Cabo.

Balandra is an absolutely amazing place. It is so peaceful and serene. It is the absolutely perfect place to spend a day. It's great for small children to play and enjoy the water safely. My 16 month old was able to wade in the water without fear of waves or rip tides. It was a
It is one of the beaches I never saw before due to the good quality of water and the scenic landscaping.

Absolutely beautiful location just 30 minutes from La Paz. In May the water is still a little chilly, but warm enough to snorkel or play... floating in the rafts was too cold. If you take snorkeling equipment, walk around the point towards the right, walk across that new beach
Don ‘t loose this place ! It is unforgettable. No doubt that is one of the best spot in Baja California

During our 7-day trip to Cabo, we opted to be courageous and drive to see the famous Balandra Beach in La Paz, Mexico. The approximately 2-5 to 3 hour drive was fun. Parking was a breeze and it wasn't packed since most folks were either in school or at work. The water was at
Balandra is by far one of my favourite beach in Mexico! It can be crowded but you can always find a spot to be on your own. It's just like paradise!!

My friend and I spent a couple days in Baja California Sur México and got a chance to take a road trip from Cabo San Lucas to La Paz BCS is around 2hrs away, we had been told about Balandra Beach, saw a couple of pictures online and decided to go, OMG!! What a beautiful place,

Everyone should take the time to visit this beach. Beautiful stunning color and very shallow to walk in. Nice short drive from Hyatt Place where we stayed 20 minutes. There are no washrooms at this beach which was the only negative. Plenty of parking and there was a good amount
We were able to rent SUP and cruise around the whole area. It was beautiful beach with clear blue water.

I have never seen a beach like this. The water is crystal clear and you can walk out so far and the water wont go past your waist. Get there early if you want an umbrella/palapas. There are about 20 of them and they get taken fast. Other than that there is no shade. We
Breath taking beach, get there early to get a shade umbrella, we arrived around 10:30 on a tuesday. Remember bug spray as the sand flies bite a lot in the shade.

We spent two days here just relaxing. A few quiet, quaint, accessible beach used by tourists and locals alike. It's not much for swimming or waves - excellent for wading, SUP/sea kayak and just enjoying the beautiful, peaceful setting. No services.. you can go to the next beach

This beach is not to miss if you are in La Paz. It’s not far and really great. But it gets crowded quite quickly, which can change the experience. Arrive early. And don’t forget to climb on the top of the small mountain next to the beach you will be rewarded by a breath taking

There are several bays and you can walk in the sea from one beach to the other. Shallow and transparent water. Lots of fishes. No services on the beach, but still it is wonderful. Must see place! You can rent a car, go by taxi or by bus from Malecon. Buses just pass every 1.5

Balandra beach was my favorite beach we visited! We drove 2.5 hours from Los Cabos to go there thanks to the locals we spoke with at our resort. They all recommended Balandra for its beauty and the shallow, beautiful waters. Balandra has beautiful white sand (in complete

This beach was lovely. The water was crystal clear and still as can be. We went to the section that you can only reach by boat, and it was very secluded which made for an incredibly peaceful experience. I recommend checking it out!

Crowded when we visited over Easter weekend. This is a beautiful beach!! I wish it hadn’t been so busy when we visited but this is a place to hang out for the day. Water is clear with lots of marine life.
This is a very beautiful beach just outside of La Paz. Totally worth the drive. Pack your own snacks...no services.

Spent several hours here with 6 adults and 6 children (ages 8-5 months). We brought our inflatable paddle boards and spent the day on our own private spot. Fun in the sun, snorkeling, and loving life.

Love Balandra Beach. My brothers and I frequent La Paz and always spend a day or two swimming around Balandra. If you can handle the trek, keep walking to the last beach in the bay. The water is clearer, and the fish are more plentiful. For a real good swim, go from Balandra
Go early in the day as it can get quite busy. Take a beach umbrella with you, there are some shade palapas but you might not get one.
Really cool semi-hidden beach. The water is pretty shallow, especially when the tide is out, so you can walk pretty far out in the water.

Samana Santa is a huge celebration here in the Baja sur. Everyone goes to the beach with family. Not just this beach, all beaches were packed. We got all the way there from San Jose del Cabo (2hr+ drive) and couldn’t even get to the beach it was so busy. Definitely bad

This place is beautiful. We were luck enough to visit when it wasn’t too crowded . The second time we went there was not parking so we left and stopped by a beach closer to La Paz but no were near as nice.

We visited Balandra Beach in the middle of the day. It is just as pictured - shallow water, nice beach, beautiful. BUT be forwarned: there are no toilets, no wind, no waves, no shells for beachcombers, & if you aren't lucky enough to snag a spot under an umbrella, it is just too
Previous posters have summed it up quite well... Playa Balandra is a beautiful place. The various hues of blue water against a backdrop of desert mountains is stunning.
Amazing beach ideal for families. You can walk forever and before the water level reaches your waist. Calm water, beautiful beach!

Such an incredible beach! Get there early to snag one of the palapas on the shore. Also pay attention to tide charts because at low tide there is almost no water in the Bay, a perfect place to go at high tide.

This beach is gorgeous. The water is so clear and shallow. We went in few feet and the water won’t go above our waste. Just make sure you bring your own food/drinks/snacks since they don’t sell anything there. Great place to relax and enjoy the view.

What a gorgeous beach. I am sure by previous posts it has already been said. We got there by 9:30 and was one of three cars. We left at 1:00 and it was packed. Several vendors for a Thurs. We rented SUP for an hour. 250 pesos an hour. Go. Enjoy. Relax!

Probably the nicest beach in La Paz! Go early as the crowds are minimal and the basin is filled with water. At low tide the basin practically empties out and you're left with wet sand. Located a 30 minute drive from the La Paz Malecon it can be challenging to get to but taxi

My husband and I travel to Cabo at least once a year, and Balandra iso ne of our favorite spots. We rent a car and drive up from our hotel. It is a swimmable beach, which if you've been to the Cab area you know that is rare. The water is beautiful, warm and calm. IT gets busy,

The Beach is beautiful, the major problem that I found is the lack of available parking lot and that there’s no restrooms available; so you should guess your options available when you gotta go... hope the authorities solve this issue because this is a great place to visit in La
Great beach. Get there early for shade. Walk to the mushroom walk and enjoy a serene beach. Shallow, but sparkling blue.
Watch out for the bus timetable - they do their own thing. We had to hitch back. No cafe/bar - take everything you need - it’s a must see.

It’s really like two crescent shaped bays connected to each other. You have to walk or wade to the right side to get to the iconic, mushroom shaped rock formation. At high tide we could walk across the bay at about waist depth, at very low tide it was about to knee depth. Out
I was completely blown away. Our trip to Cabo is complete with our day excursion at LaPaz. Balandra Beach is simply amazing. We can't wait to come back.

This is such a pretty spot. You can easily get away from the "crowds", we went on a Sunday, the busiest day of the week and it was still very peaceful. Safe, gorgeous, unspoiled, clean. You can take a short hike up a hill to get an amazing view. You can wade (it is very

This was the first stop and we only stayed 45 minutes. If I were to go again I would take an umbrella and snorkel gear. A lunch and ice chest are recommended. This is a spectacular bay and not to be missed. Warning no facilities available.

A peaceful place to spend time walking between the different beaches across from each other and next to each other. There’s a total of 7 white sand beaches. No one bothers you. You need to take your own picnic

This is a beautiful beach only 15 to 20 min drive from la Paz baja, also very shallow waters.only minor problem there aren't public bathrooms but you can drive 5 mim arond the corner to coyote beach and there is a seafood restaurant bar.

Awesome place to visit. Went at low tide, when you can walk for at least 300-400 feet and the water is just waist deep. Great place to take kids and specially those who love to see crabs and fish. The sunset from the hilltop is breathtaking. Besides some nice shades there are
You need a car or take a tour, but this place is gorgeous. There are no services - bring your own water and snacks. Good place to let the kids go in the water because it is so shallow
A must, jus be careful to take all your beach gear and food/water if you are planning to stay the day. It is a virgin beach area.
Good, clean beach that stretches for ever surrounding a huge lagoon-like area of shallow sea. Excellent for relaxing or paddle-boarding

A large perfect beach in a protected cove. About 20 palapas lined up on the beach (no charge). Very shallow water but we were able to use a kayak. OK snorkeling around the rocks on the other side of the cove. A bit cool in February but still swimable. It's about a 25 minute
Nice virgin beach. It's like a giant pool, not deep at all. Calm water. I think it could have some ecofriendly infrastructure, it´s the only thing missing to have an excellente place
Very pretty little bay, fairly clean too! Easy place to wade in the water. Had some fun helping a little fish build his house!
Beautiful beach, not crowded and much cleaner than the private resort beach! Easy short drive from town

La Paz is a very industrial port city but some of the beaches are interesting because the water is clear, very shallow and walkable. It was fun to take a hike in this area that has sand dunes and some great places for pictures.
We had a great time there, this beach has a lot of people on weekends, it is beautiful ant there is the famous stone fungus, a symbol of la Paz

Beautiful area however we went out for one hour and our camera and phone were stolen. It was super busy and we hid them in our car... I know i know... I'm in Mexico... don't leave stuff in the car but I can't exactly take everything with me out... Saddest part is all the
While driving the Baja we stopped in to check out this beach. It was nice and sheltered as this was a windy day. Great for a little kayak adventure.
I love this place! Incredible views and great place to spend a great day! Bring your own umbrella also water and things to eat because there no place to buy things!
best beach in baja shallow warm un busy would def recommend to visit about 45 mins by bus lots of other great beachs near by

Must see! Climb the hill for the view. Shallow, safe, no amenities. Easy drive from La Paz. Good parking.

I truly believe after going up and down the Baja, that by far this is the most amazing beach in all of Mexico. The sand is icing sugar white and soft, the water is clear clean warm and completely beyond words amazing
Beautiful and very clean beach! Worth the visit!! to walk on the sea its great, water is without waves.. very peaceful and beautiful place.
We spent 2 days here, SUPing and swimming and wading. Breathtaking scenery and clear, beautiful water.
This is a cool tide pool, sea life walk around beach expereince- tons of sealife all around- daughter did get a small Jellyfish sting wading in water- not without dangers but worth the great memories

Una playa muy bonita con aguas muy claras. Pero tengas cuidado con las medusas. Yo fui y me pico una. No hay servicios de sanitario y/o un lugar para comer. Hay mejores playas sin duda. Beautiful beach with crystal clear waters. But be careful with the jellyfish!! I went a few

We drove to Balandra on one of the days staying there in La Paz. It was beautiful and the fact that you can walk out so far on low tide is fun. You can also rent kayaks and take it around. The only part that I didn't like was that from the moment you drive in, you start seeing
We were there on an overcast day but it was still absolutely beautiful. Lots of tide pool critters to see and the beach was totally wadable during low tide.

Balandra was probably the highlight of our trip. Absolutely gorgeous beach, pretty secluded, if youre willing to venture along the coastline you can easily find private areas where very few people are out there. Highly recommend, only complaint is we didnt bring beer!
Shallow beach so you can walk out a long way. The water is no deeper than waist deep. It was easy to find and get too.

at high tide, it is one of the most beautiful beaches we have ever been to. But at low tide, its not as good. Also, depending on the time of year, it can get packed with lots of locals. Be sure to climb up to the top of the overlook very carefully. Lots of loose rocks, but
This place was truly amazing. The water was crystal clear with white sugar sand. The backdrop looks like a chunk of the Grand Canyon with wild cacti growing on the mounds.
Beautiful spot! The four stars are only because of the weather, which was out of our control. Highly recommended as cloudy days are extremely rare.
Just no words describe the beauty of this place. The Palapas have just been redone. Beach is very kid friendly. There are however no public restrooms and the trash cans seem to fill up quick.
We went on a Saturday. Parking lot full, palapas taken (last time I visited there were no palapas..) Still a pretty spot, but not what it was ten years ago.

One of the best beaches we visited when in Cabo. Was worth the drive of 2 hrs with screaming/hungry kids in the car. You can walk all the way across and the water would reach a little over your waist. Water is a little chilly but once you get in and with the scorching nice sun

This was a clean beach with free plapas if you get there early. You can walk around the rocks to the Flower Rock when the tide is low.

This beach is beautiful, but the day we went there were WAY too many people. The water is calm, clear and shallow. Perfect for famililes with small children and conveniently close to town. Fortunately we found other beaches nearby that weren't as congested.
Incredible sunset visit to balandra water very warm. One of the most spectacular beaches in Mexico great for snorkeling and enjoying the beach and views

Just a short 30 minute drive from La Paz, definitely the nicest beach in the area. The road is not marked very well but if you hit the ferry port you are on the right track. Nice clean shallow water, great for kids. There are many palapas on the beach but are taken by 10:30

Take everything you need, because they don't sell a thing here, but pack the cooler, some shade and spend the day swimming in this natural pool!

Perfect turquoise warm waters and white, fine sand. This is one of the most picturesque beaches we've seen and incredibly quiet. If you're in La Paz, Balandra is a must visit!

Una de las playas más bonitas que he visistado en Mexico. One of the most beautiful beaches in mexico, You might wanna go after raining season so the water level goes up.

text.wiki:
Tiwanaku (Spanish: Tiahuanaco or Tiahuanacu) is a Pre-Columbian archaeological site in western Bolivia near Lake Titicaca and one of the largest sites in South America. Surface remains currently cover around 4 square kilometers and include decorated ceramics, monumental structures, and megalithic blocks. The site's population probably peaked around AD 800 with 10,000 to 20,000 people.The site was first recorded in written history in 1549 by Spanish conquistador Pedro Cieza de León while searching for the southern Inca capital of Qullasuyu.Some have hypothesized that Tiwanaku's modern name is related to the Aymara term taypiqala, meaning "stone in the center", alluding to the belief that it lay at the center of the world. The name by which Tiwanaku was known to its inhabitants may have been lost as they had no written language. Heggarty and Beresford-Jones suggest that the  Puquina language is most likely to have been the language of Tiwanaku.


== Antiquity ==
The age of the site has been significantly refined over the last century. From 1910 to 1945, Arthur Posnansky maintained that the site was 11,000–17,000 years old based on comparisons to geological eras and archaeoastronomy. Beginning in the 1970s, Carlos Ponce Sanginés proposed the site was first occupied around 1580 BC, the site's oldest radiocarbon date. This date is still seen in some publications and museums in Bolivia. Since the 1980s, researchers have recognized this date as unreliable, leading to the consensus that the site is no older than 200 or 300 BC. Most recently, a statistical assessment of reliable radiocarbon dates estimates that the site was founded around AD 110 (50–170, 68% probability), a date supported by the lack of ceramic styles from earlier periods.


== Structures ==
The structures that have been excavated by researchers at Tiwanaku include the Akapana, Akapana East, and Pumapunku stepped platforms, the Kalasasaya, the Kheri Kala, and Putin enclosures, and the Semi-Subterranean Temple. These may be visited by the public.
The Akapana is an approximately cross-shaped pyramidal structure that is 257 m wide, 197 m broad at its maximum, and 16.5 m tall. At its center appears to have been a sunken court. This was nearly destroyed by a deep looters excavation that extends from the center of this structure to its eastern side. Material from the looter's excavation was dumped off the eastern side of the Akapana. A staircase with sculptures is present on its western side. Possible residential complexes might have occupied both the northeast and southeast corners of this structure.
Originally, the Akapana was thought to have been developed from a modified hill. Twenty-first-century studies have shown that it is an entirely manmade earthen mound, faced with a mixture of large and small stone blocks. The dirt comprising Akapana appears to have been excavated from the "moat" that surrounds the site. The largest stone block within the Akapana, made of andesite, is estimated to weigh 65.7 tonnes. The structure was possibly for the shaman-puma relationship or transformation through shape shifting. Tenon puma and human heads stud the upper terraces.

The Akapana East was built on the eastern side of early Tiwanaku. Later it was considered a boundary between the ceremonial center and the urban area. It was made of a thick, prepared floor of sand and clay, which supported a group of buildings. Yellow and red clay were used in different areas for what seems like aesthetic purposes. It was swept clean of all domestic refuse, signaling its great importance to the culture.The Pumapunku is a man-made platform built on an east-west axis like the Akapana. It is a rectangular, terraced earthen mound faced with megalithic blocks. It is 167.36 m wide along its north-south axis and 116.7 m broad along its east-west axis and is 5 m tall. Identical 20-meter-wide projections extend 27.6 meters north and south from the northeast and southeast corners of the Pumapunku. Walled and unwalled courts and an esplanade are associated with this structure.
A prominent feature of the Pumapunku is a large stone terrace; it is 6.75 by 38.72 meters in dimension and paved with large stone blocks. It is called the "Plataforma Lítica". The Plataforma Lítica contains the largest stone block found in the Tiwanaku site. According to Ponce Sangines, the block is estimated to weigh 131 metric tons. The second-largest stone block found within the Pumapunku is estimated to be 85 metric tons.

The Kalasasaya is a large courtyard more than 300 feet long, outlined by a high gateway. It is located to the north of the Akapana and west of the Semi-Subterranean Temple. Within the courtyard is where explorers found the Gateway of the Sun. Since the late 20th century, researchers have theorized that this was not the gateway's original location.
Near the courtyard is the Semi-Subterranean Temple; a square sunken courtyard that is unique for its north-south rather than east-west axis. The walls are covered with tenon heads of many different styles, suggesting that the structure was reused for different purposes over time. It was built with walls of sandstone pillars and smaller blocks of Ashlar masonry. The largest stone block in the Kalasasaya is estimated to weigh 26.95 metric tons.Within many of the site's structures are impressive gateways; the ones of monumental scale are placed on artificial mounds, platforms, or sunken courts. Many gateways show iconography of the Staff God. This iconography also is used on some oversized vessels, indicating an importance to the culture. This iconography is most present on the Gateway of the Sun.The Gateway of the Sun and others located at Pumapunku are not complete. They are missing part of a typical recessed frame known as a chambranle, which typically have sockets for clamps to support later additions. These architectural examples, as well as the recently discovered Akapana Gate, have unique detail and demonstrate high skill in stone-cutting. This reveals a knowledge of descriptive geometry. The regularity of elements suggests they are part of a system of proportions.

Many theories for the skill of Tiwanaku's architectural construction have been proposed. One is that they used a luk’ a, which is a standard measurement of about sixty centimeters. Another argument is for the Pythagorean Ratio. This idea calls for right triangles at a ratio of five to four to three used in the gateways to measure all parts. Lastly, Protzen and Nair argue that Tiwanaku had a system set for individual elements dependent on context and composition. This is shown in the construction of similar gateways ranging from diminutive to monumental size, proving that scaling factors did not affect proportion. With each added element, the individual pieces were shifted to fit together.As the population grew, occupational niches developed, and people began to specialize in certain skills. There was an increase in artisans, who worked in pottery, jewelry, and textiles. Like the later Inca, the Tiwanaku had few commercial or market institutions. Instead, the culture relied on elite redistribution. That is, the elites of the empire controlled essentially all economic output but were expected to provide each commoner with all the resources needed to perform his or her function. Selected occupations include agriculturists, herders, pastoralists, etc. Such separation of occupations was accompanied by hierarchical stratification within the empire.The elites of Tiwanaku lived inside four walls that were surrounded by a moat. This moat, some believe, was to create the image of a sacred island. Inside the walls were many images devoted to human origin, which only the elites would see. Commoners may have entered this structure only for ceremonial purposes since it was home to the holiest of shrines.


== Archaeology ==

As the site has suffered from looting and amateur excavations since shortly after Tiwanaku's fall, archeologists must attempt to interpret it with the understanding that materials have been jumbled and destroyed. This destruction continued during the Spanish conquest and colonial period, and during 19th century and the early 20th century. Other damage was committed by people quarrying stone for building and railroad construction, and target practice by military personnel.
No standing buildings have survived at the modern site. Only public, non-domestic foundations remain, with poorly reconstructed walls. The ashlar blocks used in many of these structures were mass-produced in similar styles so that they could possibly be used for multiple purposes. Throughout the period of the site, certain buildings changed purposes, causing a mix of artifacts found today.Detailed study of Tiwanaku began on a small scale in the mid-nineteenth century. In the 1860s, Ephraim George Squier visited the ruins and later published maps and sketches completed during his visit. German geologist Alphons Stübel spent nine days in Tiwanaku in 1876, creating a map of the site based on careful measurements. He also made sketches and created paper impressions of carvings and other architectural features. A book containing major photographic documentation was published in 1892 by engineer Georg von Grumbkow, With commentary by archaeologist Max Uhle, this was the first in-depth scientific account of the ruins.
Von Grumbkow had first visited Tiwanaku between the end of 1876 and the beginning of 1877, when he accompanied as a photographer the expedition of French adventurer Théodore Ber, financed by American businessman Henry Meiggs, against Ber’s promise of donating the artifacts he will find, on behalf of Meiggs, to Washington's Smithsonian Institution and the American Museum of Natural History in New York. Ber’s expedition was cut short by the violent hostility of the local population, instigated by the Catholic parish priest, but von Grumbkow’s early pictures survive.
Pictures of archaeological excavations in 1903
		
		
		


=== Contemporary excavation and restoration ===

In the 1960s, the Bolivian government initiated an effort to restore the site and reconstruct part of it. The walls of the Kalasasaya are almost all reconstructed. The original stones making up the Kalasasaya would have resembled a more "Stonehenge"-like style, spaced evenly apart and standing straight up. The reconstruction was not sufficiently based on research; for instance, a new wall was built around Kalasasaya. The reconstruction does not have as high quality of stonework as was present in Tiwanaku. As noted, the Gateway of the Sun, now in the Kalasasaya, is believed to have been moved from its original location.Modern, academically sound archaeological excavations were performed from 1978 through the 1990s by University of Chicago anthropologist Alan Kolata and his Bolivian counterpart, Oswaldo Rivera. Among their contributions are the rediscovery of the suka kollus, accurate dating of the civilization's growth and influence, and evidence for a drought-based collapse of the Tiwanaku civilization.
Archaeologists such as Paul Goldstein have argued that the Tiwanaku empire ranged outside of the altiplano area and into the Moquegua Valley in Peru. Excavations at Omo settlements show signs of similar architecture characteristic of Tiwanaku, such as a temple and terraced mound. Evidence of similar types of cranial vault modification in burials between the Omo site and the main site of Tiwanaku is also being used for this argument.

Today Tiwanaku has been designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, administered by the Bolivian government.
Recently, the Department of Archaeology of Bolivia (DINAR, directed by Javier Escalante) has been conducting excavations on the Akapana pyramid. The Proyecto Arqueologico Pumapunku-Akapana (Pumapunku-Akapana Archaeological Project, PAPA) run by the University of Pennsylvania, has been excavating in the area surrounding the pyramid for the past few years, and also conducting Ground Penetrating Radar surveys of the area.
In former years, an archaeological field school offered through Harvard's Summer School Program, conducted in the residential area outside the monumental core, has provoked controversy amongst local archaeologists. The program was directed by Dr. Gary Urton, of Harvard, who was an expert on quipus, and Dr. Alexei Vranich of the University of Pennsylvania. The controversy was over allowing a team of untrained students to work on the site, even under professional supervision. It was so important that only certified professional archaeologists with documented funding were allowed access. The controversy was charged with nationalistic and political undertones. The Harvard field school lasted for three years, beginning in 2004 and ending in 2007. The project was not renewed in subsequent years, nor was permission sought to do so.
In 2009 state-sponsored restoration work on the Akapana pyramid was halted due to a complaint from UNESCO. The restoration had consisted of facing the pyramid with adobe, although researchers had not established this as appropriate.In 2013, marine archaeologists exploring Lake Titicaca's Khoa reef discovered an ancient ceremonial site and lifted artefacts such as a lapis lazuli and ceramic figurines, incense burners and a ceremonial medallion from the lake floor. The artifacts are representative of the lavishness of the ceremonies and the Tiwanaku culture.


== See also ==


== References ==

Hoshower, Lisa M., Jane E. Buikstra, Paul S. Goldstein, and Ann D. Webster, "Artificial Cranial Deformation at the Omo M10 Site: A Tiwanaku Complex from the Moquegua Valley, Peru", Latin American Antiquity, Vol. 6, No. 2 (June, 1995) pp. 145–64, Society for American Archaeology.

Kolata, Alan L (June 1991), "The Technology and Organization of Agricultural Production in the Tiwanaku State", Latin American Antiquity, Society for American Archaeology, 2 (2): 99–125, doi:10.2307/972273, JSTOR 972273.

Reinhard, Johan, "Chavin and Tiahuanaco: A New Look at Two Andean Ceremonial Centers." National Geographic Research 1(3): 395–422, 1985.
——— (1990), "Tiahuanaco, Sacred Center of the Andes",  in McFarren, Peter (ed.), An Insider's Guide to Bolivia, La Paz, pp. 151–81.
——— (1992), "Tiwanaku: Ensayo sobre su cosmovisión" [Tiwanaku: essay on its cosmovision], Revista Pumapunku (in Spanish), 2: 8–66.

text.wiki:
La Paz (), officially known as Nuestra Señora de La Paz (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈnwestɾa seˈɲoɾa ðe la ˈpas]; English: "Our Lady of Peace"), also named Chuqi Yapu (Chuquiago) in Aymara, is the seat of government of the Plurinational State of Bolivia. With an estimated 816,044 residents as of 2020, La Paz is the third-most populous city in Bolivia. Its metropolitan area, which is formed by La Paz, El Alto, Achocalla, Viacha, and Mecapaca makes up the second most populous urban area in Bolivia, with a population of 1.8 million, after Santa Cruz de la Sierra with a population of 2.3 million. It is also the capital of the La Paz Department.
The city, located in west-central Bolivia 68 km (42 mi) southeast of Lake Titicaca, is set in a canyon created by the Choqueyapu River. It is located in a bowl-like depression surrounded by the high mountains of the Altiplano. Overlooking the city is the towering, triple-peaked Illimani. Its peaks are always snow-covered and can be seen from many parts of the city. At an elevation of roughly 3,650 m (11,975 ft) above sea level, La Paz is the highest capital city in the world. Due to its altitude, La Paz has an unusual subtropical highland climate, with rainy summers and dry winters.
La Paz was founded on October 20, 1548 by the Spanish conquistador Captain Alonso de Mendoza at the site of the Inca settlement of Laja as a connecting point between the commercial routes that led from Potosí and Oruro to Lima; the full name of the city was originally Nuestra Señora de La Paz (meaning Our Lady of Peace) in commemoration of the restoration of peace following the insurrection of Gonzalo Pizarro and fellow conquistadors against the first viceroy of Peru. The city was later moved to its present location in the valley of Chuquiago Marka. La Paz was under Spanish colonial rule as part of the Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata, before Bolivia gained independence. Since its founding, the city was the site of numerous revolts. In 1781, the indigenous leader and independence activist Túpac Katari laid siege to the city for a total of six months, but was finally defeated. On July 16, 1809 the Bolivian patriot Pedro Domingo Murillo ignited a revolution for independence, marking the beginning of the Spanish American Wars of Independence, which gained the freedom of South American states in 1821.As the seat of the government of Bolivia, La Paz is the site of the Palacio Quemado, the presidential palace. It is also the seat of the Bolivian legislature, the Plurinational Legislative Assembly, and numerous government departments and agencies. The constitutional capital of Bolivia, Sucre, retains the judicial power. The city hosts all the foreign embassies as well as international missions in the country. La Paz is an important political, administrative, economic, and sports center of Bolivia; it generates 24% of the nation's Gross Domestic Product and serves as the headquarters for numerous Bolivian companies and industries.La Paz is also an important cultural center of Latin America, as it hosts several landmarks belonging to the colonial times, such as the San Francisco Church, the Metropolitan Cathedral, the Plaza Murillo and Jaén Street. The city is renowned for its unique markets, particularly the Witches' Market, and for its vibrant nightlife. Its unusual topography offers unique views of the city and the surrounding mountains of the Cordillera Real from numerous natural viewing points. La Paz is also home to the largest urban cable car network in the world. In May 2015, it was officially recognized as one of the New 7 Wonders Cities together with Beirut, Doha, Durban, Havana, Kuala Lumpur and Vigan. La Paz is listed on the Global Cities Index 2015, and is considered a global city type "Gamma" by Globalization and World Cities Research Network (GaWC).


== History ==

This area had been the site of an Inca city, located on a major trading route.
Although the Spanish conquistadors entered the area in 1535, they did not found La Paz until 1548. Originally it was to be at the site of the Native American settlement, Laja, with the full name of the city being Nuestra Señora de La Paz (meaning Our Lady of Peace). The name commemorated the restoration of peace following the insurrection of Gonzalo Pizarro and fellow conquistadors four years earlier against Blasco Núñez Vela, the first viceroy of Peru. The town site was moved a few days later to its present location in the valley of Chuquiago, which is more clement.Control over the former Inca lands had been entrusted to Pedro de la Gasca by the Spanish king (and Holy Roman Emperor) Emperor Charles V. Gasca commanded Alonso de Mendoza to found a new city commemorating the end of the civil wars in Peru; the city of La Paz was founded on October 20, 1548 by Alonzo de Mendoza, with Juan de Vargas appointed as its first mayor.In 1549, Juan Gutierrez Paniagua was commanded to design an urban plan that would designate sites for public areas, plazas, official buildings, and a cathedral. These were meant to express the ideals and relationships of Spanish colonial society. La Plaza de los Españoles, which is known today as the Plaza Murillo, was chosen as the location for government buildings as well as the Metropolitan Cathedral.
Spain controlled La Paz with a firm grip and the Spanish king had the last word in all matters political, but consultation was extended, taking months or longer by sea. Indigenous and other unrest was repeated around the turn of the nineteenth century. In 1781, for a total of six months, a group of Aymara people laid siege to La Paz. Under the leadership of Tupac Katari, they destroyed churches and government property. Thirty years later Indians conducted a two-month siege against La Paz. This incident was the setting for the origin of the legend of the Ekeko. In 1809 the struggle for independence from the Spanish rule brought uprisings against the royalist forces. On July 16, 1809 Pedro Domingo Murillo said that the Bolivian revolution was igniting a lamp that nobody would be able to turn off. This uprising formally marked the beginning of the liberation of South America from Spain. The first open rebellions against the Spanish Crown took place in La Paz and the city of Sucre simultaneously. This event is known as the Primer Grito Libertario de América.
Pedro Domingo Murillo was hanged at the Plaza de los Españoles that night. After Bolivia gained independence, La Paz named this plaza after him, to commemorate him always. He is remembered as the voice of revolution across South America.
In 1825, after the decisive victory of the republicans at Ayacucho over the Spanish army in the course of the Spanish American wars of independence, the city's full name was changed to La Paz de Ayacucho (meaning The Peace of Ayacucho).

In 1898, La Paz was made the de facto seat of the national government, with Sucre remaining the nominal historical as well as judiciary capital. This change reflected the shift of the Bolivian economy away from the largely exhausted silver mines of Potosí to the exploitation of tin near Oruro, and resulting shifts in the distribution of economic and political power among various national elites.


== Geography ==

La Paz is built in a canyon created by the Choqueyapu River (now mostly built over), which runs northwest to southeast. The city's main thoroughfare, which roughly follows the river, changes names over its length, but the central tree-lined section running through the downtown core is called the Prado.
The geography of La Paz (in particular the altitude) is marked by social differences. The more affluent residents live in the lower, central areas of the city southwest of the Prado. Many middle-class residents live in high-rise condos near the center. Lower-income residents live in makeshift brick houses in the surrounding hills.
The satellite city of El Alto, in which the airport is located, is spread over a broad area to the west of the canyon, on the Altiplano. La Paz is renowned for its unique markets, unusual and dramatic topography, and traditional culture.
La Paz is located in the valleys of the Andes, close to the Eastern split of the Altiplano region. It is closer to such notable mountains as the Illimani (guardian of La Paz), Huayna Potosi, Mururata, and Illampu. On the Western side of the Altiplano divide, about an hour to the west of the La Paz, is the Sajama Volcano, the tallest mountain in Bolivia and ninth-tallest mountain in the Andes.
In July 1994, an earthquake rated at 8.2 struck just 200 miles (322 km) north of La Paz. It could be felt near La Paz and caused damage throughout the villages of the area.


=== Climate ===
At more than 4,000 metres (13,000 ft) above sea level, higher parts of La Paz have an unusual subtropical highland climate (Cwc, according to the Köppen climate classification), with subpolar oceanic characteristics (less than 4 months have a mean temperature above 10 °C), bordering on a tundra climate (ET). The whole city has rainy summers and dry winters. Night-time temperatures range from cold to very cold. Snow flurries can occur in winter, especially at dawn and it usually melts before noon. At these high altitudes despite being located only 16 degrees from the equator, the city's average temperature is similar to that of cities such as Bergen, Norway or Tórshavn, Faroe Islands, located as far as 60 and 62 degrees from the equator respectively.
The temperatures in the central La Paz, at 3,600 metres (11,811 feet), and in the Zona Sur (Southern Zone), at 3,250 m (10,663 ft) above sea level, are warmer (subtropical highland climate Cwb, according to the Köppen classification).
Owing to the altitude of the city, temperatures are consistently cool to mild throughout the year, though the diurnal temperature variation is typically large. The city has a relatively dry climate, with rainfall occurring mainly in the slightly warmer months of November to March.
In the highest part of the city, above 4,000 metres, the two cloudiest months are February and March, in late summer, when sunshine averages around 5 hours per day. The two sunniest months are June and July, in winter, when sunshine averages around 8 hours per day.Heavy precipitation typically occurs throughout summer, and often causes destructive mudslides. At an altitude of 3,250 metres, in the southern part of the city, the wettest month is January with a monthly average of 114 mm (4.5 in), and the driest is July with 8 mm (0.3 in).
The warmest temperature recorded was 27.0 °C (80.6 °F) and the coldest was −12.5 °C (9.5 °F).


== Districts and neighborhoods ==


=== Main neighborhoods and zones ===

San Jorge
Located in the district known as Cotahuma and near Sopocachi, is one of the main residential and diplomatic areas of the city. San Jorge is one of the most exclusive neighborhoods of La Paz and the financial center of the metropolis, housing international firms like Deloitte, Bank of America, Ernst & Young, BBVA and the famous Ritz Hotel. It is now home of Bolivia's tallest building known as Torre Girasoles, and the only intelligent building of the country, known as Torre Azul. The neighborhood is also populated with expensive offices, renowned restaurants, museums and bookstores. Its Avenida Arce, one of the main streets of the city, is the highest-priced street in the country and the one with the most upscale boutiques in Bolivia. San Jorge is home to the embassies of the United States, the United Kingdom, Brazil, Japan, Germany and Spain. The offices of the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank, the CAF – Development Bank of Latin America, the Goethe Institut, the Alliance Française and the Dante Alighieri Society are also located in this modern neighborhood.Sopocachi
Located in the 1st District (Cotahuma), Sopocachi is probably one of the oldest residential neighborhoods, 10 minutes from the center of the city. Despite the expansion and development of the area, this quarter maintained its residential property. In the last years, there has been an important commercial expansion, mainly on the surroundings of Abaroa Square, one of the many squares and parks of the zone.San Pedro
Located in the 1st District (Cotahuma), on the right bank of the Choqueyapu River and built around the "Plaza de San Pedro" (official name: Plaza Sucre, Sucre Square), is home to numerous shops, businesses and small enterprises, especially printing, spare parts and auto maintenance and repair shops. San Pedro's "Rodriguez Market" remains as one of the most popular middle-class and oldest of the city. The San Pedro prison is here.Centro
The city's downtown area, in the 7th District, comprising the center of La Paz and principal roads of the city, like Arce Avenue, July 16 Avenue (also known as "Prado Avenue"), Mariscal Santa Cruz Avenue and Camacho Avenue — the last one being the home of the headquarters of the principal banks and companies of the country.
Casco Viejo
Located in the 7th District, is the historic and ancient center of La Paz. It now houses museums, hotels, shops and buildings as the Mayor City of La Paz and the Central Bank of Bolivia. In the Old Quarter is the Plaza Murillo, which is home to the Government Palace and the National Congress.
Miraflores
In the 7th District, Miraflores district is separated from downtown by a long barrel (Parque Urbano Central, "Central Urban Park") and connected by the Bridge of the Americas and two avenues. Originally a residential zone, its growth has led it to become a major recreational center. It houses universities (including the Universidad Mayor de San Andrés's faculty of medicine), hospitals and the Estadio Hernando Siles (capacity of 45,000 people).Northern District
Located in the 2nd and 3rd districts, it has a significant industrial activity (mainly food), being the Cervecería Boliviana Nacional (Bolivian National Brewery) the most significant industry founded by Germans, and one of the city's biggest companies in the country. It connects La Paz with the city of El Alto by the autopista (highway).Southern District
In the 5th district; has less height than the rest of La Paz (3,200 to 2,800 meters). This area houses some of the most affluent and exclusive neighborhoods of the city, like Obrajes, Irpavi, Calacoto, La Florida and Achumani, among others. It has been benefited from steady economic growth and is now the second commercial and financial center of the city, housing international firms like Moody's, Citibank, Aon Corporation, Huawei, Millicom International Cellular, Nissan Motor Corporation, Samsung Electronics, Pan American Silver Corporation, a Sumitomo Corporation branch, Ernst & Young, and the "MegaCenter", La Paz's biggest shopping mall.


== Cityscape ==


== Colonial architecture ==
The city of La Paz has a consistently decreasing volume of colonial buildings, mostly centered around the vicinity of the Plaza Murillo. Due to a lack of funds and the inability of property owners to pay for restorations to colonial buildings, many have been torn down, or are in a dilapidated state. As historic buildings are more expensive to keep, land owners find it less of a burden to construct more modern buildings as opposed to keeping the old ones. Although there has been an increasing number of projects and propositions to restore some of the city's colonial buildings, the future of these historic edifices remains uncertain.


== Economy ==

The economy of La Paz has improved greatly in recent years, mainly as a result of improved political stability. Due to the long period of high inflation and economic struggle faced by Bolivians in the 1980s and early 1990s, a large informal economy developed. Evidence of this is provided by the markets found all around the city. 
While there are stable markets, almost every street in the downtown area and surrounding neighborhoods has at least one vendor on it.
La Paz remains the principal center of manufacturing enterprises that produce finished-product goods for the country, with about two-thirds of Bolivia's manufacturing located nearby. 
Historically, industry in Bolivia has been dominated by mineral processing and the preparation of agricultural products. However, in the urban centre of La Paz, small plants carry out a large portion of the industry. Food, tobacco products, clothing, various consumer goods, building materials, and agricultural tools are produced. "The tin quotations from London are watched in La Paz with close interest as an index of the country's prosperity; a third of the national revenue and more than half of the total customs in 1925 were derived from tin; in short, that humble but indispensable metal is the hub around which Bolivia's economic life revolves.  The tin deposits of Bolivia, second largest in the world, ... invite development."


== Sports ==
La Paz is the home of some of the biggest football teams in Bolivia.

Club Bolivar : Founded in 1925, it was named in honor of the Libertador Simón Bolívar, the team has won most of the tournaments national and international championships in the last 20 years, and is the largest team, by number of fans, of the country. In the year 1964 was a bad year, and it lost the category, playing the next year in the second category, but returning afterwards.The Strongest : Founded in 1908 the club hosts some of its games and trains on their home stadium named Rafael Mendoza after Don Rafael Mendoza, one of the most important presidents of the club. In 1968 an airplane accident took the life of almost all the players, but Rafael Mendoza made many efforts that allowed the team to rise again as one of the most important in the country.

La Paz F.C. : Founded in 1989, the club quickly rose through the ranks to become the third major club in the capital, only behind in popularity to the two well-established city rivals.The city is host to several other teams that play in the first and second divisions such as:

Academia de Balompié Boliviano
Always Ready
Chaco Petrolero
Club 31 de Octubre
Deportivo Municipal de La Paz
